This expository blog post on Baire Spaces was my submission as a project for a topology course taught by Professor Mike Miller Eismeier at Columbia University. A prospective reader should have done a first course in topology and analysis; everything else is developed from scratch. I have freely borrowed and modified from all the references listed at the end.

“The Baire category is a profound triviality which condenses the folk wisdom of a generation of ingenious mathematicians into a single statement.” Tom Körner (Körner, 2008)

INTRODUCTION

Every mathematician has a few tricks (Rota, 2008) which form the foundation of their toolkit that they apply skilfully to a great variety of problems (Tao, 2021). One of the goals of this expository blog post is to convince the reader that Baire category theorems are a worthwhile addition to their toolkit. The other goal is to simply indulge in the study of Baire spaces for it is beautiful mathematics.

Small Sets

What is a “small” set? This question can have multiple answers depending on whom you ask. For a set theorist, a countable set is small, while for an analyst, a set of measure 000 is small. We will see that for a topologist the ideas of nowhere dense set and meager set encapsulate the notion of smallness. These different notions of smallness don't always coincide though. For example, Cantor set is an uncountable set having Lebesgue measure 000, and as we will see in Section 2 it is also nowhere dense in R.\mathbb R.R.

Using this topological vocabulary for small sets we will define the notion of a Baire space, which in this vocabulary aren't small. Many well-behaved classes of spaces are Baire. Among the most well-known are locally compact Hausdorff spaces and complete pseudometric spaces. This is the content of the famous Baire category theorems which will be the highlight of this blog post.

These Baire category theorems are a powerful class of results useful for proving existence. We will see in Section ?? how they can be applied to prove existence of objects of desired property. The main idea which these applications follow is to first construct a set XXX in which we want to prove there exist elements satisfying a certain property, and then show that elements not satisfying this property, in fact, form a small set.

Warm-Up

As a warm-up to the kind of arguments we will be dealing with let's show that every nonempty compact Hausdorff space with no isolated points is uncountable. This will in particular show that [0,1][0,1][0,1] is uncountable.

We first show that given any nonempty open set UUU of XXX and any point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, there exists a nonempty open set VVV contained in UUU such that xxx is not contained in the closure clX(V)\mathrm{cl}_X(V)clX​(V) of VVV in X.X.X. If x∈Ux \in Ux∈U, then since {x}\{x\}{x} is not open, UUU must contain a point different from x.x.x. On other hand, if x∉Ux \notin Ux∈/U, then since UUU is nonempty it must contain a point different from x.x.x. In either case denote this point by y.y.y. XXX is Hausdorff, and therefore we can choose two disjoint open subsets W1,W2W_1, W_2W1​,W2​ of XXX such that x∈W1x \in W_1x∈W1​ and y∈W2.y \in W_2.y∈W2​. Then let V=W2∩U.V = W_2 \cap U.V=W2​∩U.  It is an open set contained in UUU, it is nonempty because it contains yyy, and its closure does not contain x.x.x.

To finish proving that XXX is uncountable we show that any given function f ⁣:N→Xf \colon \mathbb N \to Xf:N→X is not surjective. Let xn=f(n).x_n = f(n).xn​=f(n). Apply our result above to the nonempty open set U=XU = XU=X to choose a nonempty open subset V1V_1V1​ of XXX such that x1∉clX(V1).x_1 \notin \mathrm{cl}_X(V_1).x1​∈/clX​(V1​). In general, for each n∈N,n \in \mathbb N,n∈N, given nonempty open subset VnV_{n}Vn​ of XXX, choose Vn+1V_{n+1}Vn+1​ using the result above such that Vn+1⊆VnV_{n+1} \subseteq V_nVn+1​⊆Vn​ and xn+1∉clX(Vn+1).x_{n+1} \notin \mathrm{cl}_X(V_{n+1}).xn+1​∈/clX​(Vn+1​). We get a nested sequence

clX(V1)⊇clX(V2)⊇⋯ \mathrm{cl}_X(V_1) \supseteq \mathrm{cl}_X(V_2) \supseteq \cdots clX​(V1​)⊇clX​(V2​)⊇⋯

of nonempty closed subsets of X.X.X. Now recall the classical result that a topological space XXX is compact if and only if for every collection C\mathcal{C}C of closed subsets of XXX having the finite intersection property (i.e., every finite sub-collection of C\mathcal{C}C has nonempty intersection), the intersection ⋂C∈CC\bigcap_{C \in \mathcal{C}} C⋂C∈C​C is nonempty (See Proposition ?? for a proof). Therefore, there exists a point x∈⋂nclX(Vn).x \in \bigcap_n \mathrm{cl}_X(V_n).x∈⋂n​clX​(Vn​). Now xxx cannot equal xnx_nxn​ for any n∈N,n \in \mathbb N,n∈N, since xxx is in clX(Vn)\mathrm{cl}_X(V_n)clX​(Vn​) but xnx_nxn​ is not. Therefore, fff is not surjective.

We showed that XXX cannot be written as a countable union of singletons. A compact Hausdorff space is T1T_1T1​, i.e., for any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the singleton {x}\{x\}{x} is closed. We will show later that the singletons {x}\{x\}{x} in this case are what is called nowhere dense, and that XXX cannot be written as a countable union of nowhere dense sets. This is exactly the content of Baire category theorems, and therefore we could have concluded uncountability directly from these theorems.

PREREQUISITES

In this section we give a brief tour of the prerequisites from point-set topology, mainly for notational convenience. For a more comprehensive treatment see the excellent textbooks (Munkres, 2000), (Willard, 2004), (Engelking, 1989).

We start by recalling the notions of interior and closure which will be used in defining the notions of dense and nowhere dense sets in a topological space. As we mentioned before they provide a topological vocabulary to deal with “large” and “small” sets. Throughout we simply write XXX for a topological space (X,T).(X, \mathcal{T}).(X,T).

Definition 2.1 (Interior and Closure): Given a subset SSS of a topological space XXX, the interior of SSS in XXX, denoted intX(S)\mathrm{int}_X(S)intX​(S), is defined as the union of all open sets contained in SSS, and the closure of SSS in XXX, denoted clX(S)\mathrm{cl}_X(S)clX​(S), is defined as the intersection of all closed sets containing S.S.S.

Note that intX(S)\mathrm{int}_X(S)intX​(S) is an open set in XXX and clX(S)\mathrm{cl}_X(S)clX​(S) is a closed set in X.X.X. The reason for our cumbersome but informative notation, as opposed to the commonly used concise but uninformative notation S∘S^\circS∘ and S‾\overline{S}S for interior and closure respectively, will become clear later as we take interiors and closures under different topological spaces. It also emphasizes the important point that these operations depend on the topological space; for example, intR(R)=R\mathrm{int}_{\mathbb R}(\mathbb R) = \mathbb RintR​(R)=R but intR2(R)=∅.\mathrm{int}_{\mathbb R^2}(\mathbb R) = \varnothing.intR2​(R)=∅.

Proposition 2.2 (Equivalent characterization of closure): Given a subset SSS of a topological space XXX, x∈clX(S)x \in \mathrm{cl}_X(S)x∈clX​(S) if and only if every open subset UUU of XXX containing xxx intersects S.S.S.
We show that x∉clX(S)x \notin \mathrm{cl}_X(S)x∈/clX​(S) if and only if there exists an open subset UUU of XXX containing xxx that does not intersect S.S.S. If x∉clX(S),x \notin \mathrm{cl}_X(S),x∈/clX​(S), the set U=X∖clX(S)U = X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(S)U=X∖clX​(S) is an open subset of XXX containing xxx that does not intersect S.S.S. Conversely, if there exists an open subset UUU of XXX containing xxx that does not intersect S,S,S, then X∖UX \setminus UX∖U is a closed subset of XXX containing S.S.S. By the definition of the closure, the set X∖UX \setminus UX∖U must contain clX(S)\mathrm{cl}_X(S)clX​(S), implying x∉clX(S).x \notin \mathrm{cl}_X(S).x∈/clX​(S).
Proposition 2.3 (Complements of interior and closure): For any subset SSS of a topological space X,X,X, X∖intX(S)=clX(X∖S)X \setminus \mathrm{int}_X(S) = \mathrm{cl}_X(X \setminus S)X∖intX​(S)=clX​(X∖S) and X∖clX(S)=intX(X∖S).X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(S) = \mathrm{int}_X(X \setminus S).X∖clX​(S)=intX​(X∖S).
This follows immediately from the definitions of closure and interior, and the De Morgan's laws:
X∖intX(S)=X∖⋃U⊆SU open in XU=⋂U⊆SU open in X(X∖U)=⋂X∖U⊇X∖SX∖U closed in X(X∖U)=⋂C⊇X∖SC closed in XC=clX(X∖S),X∖clX(S)=X∖⋂C⊇SC closed in XC=⋃C⊇SC closed in X(X∖C)=⋃X∖C⊆X∖SX∖C open in X(X∖C)=⋃U⊆X∖SU open in XU=intX(X∖S). X \setminus \mathrm{int}_X(S) = X \setminus \bigcup_{\substack{U \subseteq S \\ U \text{ open in } X}} U = \bigcap_{\substack{U \subseteq S \\ U \text{ open in } X}} (X \setminus U) = \bigcap_{\substack{X \setminus U \supseteq X \setminus S \\ X \setminus U \text{ closed in } X}} (X \setminus U) = \bigcap_{\substack{C \supseteq X \setminus S \\ C \text{ closed in } X}} C = \mathrm{cl}_X(X \setminus S), \\ \begin{align*} X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(S) = X \setminus \bigcap_{\substack{C \supseteq S \\ C \text{ closed in } X}} C = \bigcup_{\substack{C \supseteq S \\ C \text{ closed in } X}} (X \setminus C) = \bigcup_{\substack{X \setminus C \subseteq X \setminus S \\ X \setminus C \text{ open in } X}} (X \setminus C) = \bigcup_{\substack{U \subseteq X \setminus S \\ U \text{ open in } X}} U = \mathrm{int}_X(X \setminus S). \end{align*} X∖intX​(S)=X∖U⊆SU open in X​⋃​U=U⊆SU open in X​⋂​(X∖U)=X∖U⊇X∖SX∖U closed in X​⋂​(X∖U)=C⊇X∖SC closed in X​⋂​C=clX​(X∖S),X∖clX​(S)=X∖C⊇SC closed in X​⋂​C=C⊇SC closed in X​⋃​(X∖C)=X∖C⊆X∖SX∖C open in X​⋃​(X∖C)=U⊆X∖SU open in X​⋃​U=intX​(X∖S).​
Definition 2.4 (Dense and nowhere dense): A subset SSS of a topological space XXX is said to be dense in XXX if its closure equals XXX, i.e., clX(S)=X.\mathrm{cl}_X(S)=X.clX​(S)=X. SSS is called nowhere dense or rare in XXX if its closure has empty interior, i.e., intX(clX(S))=∅.\mathrm{int}_X(\mathrm{cl}_X(S)) = \varnothing.intX​(clX​(S))=∅.

Nowhere dense sets give a precise meaning to “sparsely populated sets” or “sets with holes” (see the characterization in Proposition ?? (c) for a more concrete depiction of this). Nowhere dense is a strengthening of the condition “not dense” (every nowhere dense set is not dense, but the converse is false).

We immediately give equivalent characterizations of dense and nowhere dense sets which we will freely use.

Proposition 2.5 (Equivalent characterizations of dense sets): Let SSS be a subset of the topological space X.X.X. Then SSS is dense in XXX if and only if SSS has nonempty intersection with every nonempty open subset of X.X.X.
SSS is dense in XXX means clX(S)=X,\mathrm{cl}_X(S) = X,clX​(S)=X, which using Proposition 2.3 can written as intX(X∖S)=∅.\mathrm{int}_X(X \setminus S) = \varnothing.intX​(X∖S)=∅. By the definition of interior this means that the only open set disjoint from SSS is the empty set.

In the next proposition, and anywhere else, unless specified otherwise, a subspace is endowed with the subspace topology.

Proposition 2.6 (Dense subset of a dense set is itself dense): Suppose XXX is a topological space and T⊆S⊆XT \subseteq S \subseteq XT⊆S⊆X are subspaces with TTT dense in SSS and SSS dense in X.X.X. Then TTT is dense in X.X.X.
Let UUU be a nonempty open subset of X.X.X. Then U∩SU \cap SU∩S in nonempty by Proposition 5. Now note that U∩SU \cap SU∩S is an open subset of SSS in the subspace topology, and therefore (U∩S)∩T(U \cap S) \cap T(U∩S)∩T is also nonempty. But this implies that TTT is dense in X.X.X.

Proposition 2.7 (Equivalent characterisations of nowhere dense sets): Let SSS be a subset of the topological space X.X.X. Then the following are equivalent:

(a) SSS is nowhere dense in X.X.X.

(b) X∖clX(S)X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(S)X∖clX​(S) is dense in X.X.X.

(c) Every nonempty open subset UUU of XXX contains a nonempty open subset VVV that is disjoint from S.S.S.

(d) SSS is not dense in any nonempty open subset UUU of X.X.X.

The proof is pretty simple and involves simple manipulation of the definitions.

(a)  ⟺  (b)(a) \iff (b)(a)⟺(b): SSS is nowhere dense in XXX means intX(clX(S)=∅,\mathrm{int}_X(\mathrm{cl}_X(S) = \varnothing,intX​(clX​(S)=∅, which using Proposition 3 can written as clX(X∖clX(S))=X,\mathrm{cl}_X(X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(S)) = X,clX​(X∖clX​(S))=X, i.e., X∖clX(S)X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(S)X∖clX​(S) is dense in X.X.X.

(b)  ⟹  (c)(b) \implies (c)(b)⟹(c): If S=∅S = \varnothingS=∅ then (c)(c)(c) holds trivially, so suppose SSS is nonempty. Then Propositions 3 and 5 imply that every nonempty open subset UUU of XXX intersects intX(X∖S).\mathrm{int}_X(X \setminus S).intX​(X∖S). Note that intX(X∖S)\mathrm{int}_X(X \setminus S)intX​(X∖S) is an open set disjoint from SSS and thus we can let V=U∩intX(X∖S).V = U \cap \mathrm{int}_X(X \setminus S).V=U∩intX​(X∖S).

(c)  ⟹  (b)(c) \implies (b)(c)⟹(b): If every nonempty open subset UUU of XXX contains a nonempty open subset VVV that is disjoint from S,S,S, then every nonempty open subset UUU of XXX intersects the open set intX(X∖S),\mathrm{int}_X(X \setminus S),intX​(X∖S), which by Propositions 3 and 5 implies (b).(b).(b).

Example 2.8: These examples should help develop intuition.

  1. The set of rationals Q\mathbb QQ is dense in R,\mathbb R,R, and hence not nowhere dense in R.\mathbb R.R.

  2. R\mathbb RR is nowhere dense in Rn\mathbb R^nRn for n>1.n > 1.n>1.

  3. The integers Z\ZZ are nowhere dense in R.\mathbb R.R. However, Z∪(a,b)\Z \cup (a,b)Z∪(a,b) for a<b∈Ra < b \in \mathbb Ra<b∈R is not nowhere dense in R\mathbb RR since it is dense in (a,b).(a,b).(a,b). Z∪(a,b)\Z \cup (a,b)Z∪(a,b) is not dense in R\mathbb RR either.

  4. The set S={1n}n∈NS = \left\{\frac{1}{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}S={n1​}n∈N​ is nowhere dense in R,\mathbb R,R, since its closure clR(S)=S∪{0}\mathrm{cl}_{\mathbb R}(S) = S \cup \{0\}clR​(S)=S∪{0} has empty interior in R.\mathbb R.R.

  5. Suppose XXX is a T1T_1T1​ space, i.e., for any x∈X,x \in X,x∈X, the singleton {x}\{x\}{x} is closed, and suppose that the singletons are not isolated, i.e., for any x∈X,x \in X,x∈X, the singleton {x}\{x\}{x} is not open. Then singletons are nowhere dense. This is true, for example, if XXX is Rn\mathbb R^nRn for any n∈N.{n \in \mathbb N}.n∈N.

  6. The Cantor set CCC is nowhere dense in R.\mathbb R.R. To see this first recall that the Cantor set is constructed using the decreasing sequence {Cn}n≥0\{C_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Cn​}n≥0​ of closed sets defined as follows: C0=[0,1],C_0 = [0,1],C0​=[0,1], C1=[0,1/3]∪[2/3,1],C_1 = [0, 1/3] \cup [2/3, 1],C1​=[0,1/3]∪[2/3,1], C2=[0,1/9]∪[2/9,3/9]∪[6/9,7/9]∪[8/9,1],C_2 = [0, 1/9] \cup [2/9, 3/9] \cup [6/9, 7/9] \cup [8/9, 1],C2​=[0,1/9]∪[2/9,3/9]∪[6/9,7/9]∪[8/9,1], and so on, where at each step to get Cn+1C_{n+1}Cn+1​ from CnC_nCn​ we remove the middle third open interval from each of the 2n2^n2n closed disjoint subsets of Cn.C_n.Cn​. The Cantor set is the countable intersection C=⋂n∈NCn.C = \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} C_n.C=⋂n∈N​Cn​. CCC is therefore nowhere dense since CnC_nCn​ contains no interval of length greater than 1/3n.1/3^n.1/3n.

  7. Suppose XXX is a topological space and S⊆X.S \subseteq X.S⊆X. The boundary of SSS in X,X,X, denoted bdX(S)\mathrm{bd}_X(S)bdX​(S) is defined to be the closed set clX(S)∩clX(X∖S).\mathrm{cl}_X(S) \cap \mathrm{cl}_X(X \setminus S).clX​(S)∩clX​(X∖S). The neighborhood of any point in bdX(S)\mathrm{bd}_X(S)bdX​(S) intersects both SSS and X∖S.X \setminus S.X∖S. Therefore, if SSS is open in X,X,X, bdX(S)⊆X∖S,\mathrm{bd}_X(S) \subseteq X \setminus S,bdX​(S)⊆X∖S, and thus intX(bdX(S))=∅.\mathrm{int}_X(\mathrm{bd}_X(S)) = \varnothing.intX​(bdX​(S))=∅. Similarly, if SSS is closed, bdX(S)⊆S\mathrm{bd}_X(S) \subseteq SbdX​(S)⊆S and thus intX(bdX(S))=∅.\mathrm{int}_X(\mathrm{bd}_X(S)) = \varnothing.intX​(bdX​(S))=∅. In other words, boundaries of open or closed sets is nowhere dense, and also a closed set is nowhere dense if and only if it coincides with its boundary.

Properties Of Nowhere Dense Sets

We next define an ideal and a σ−\sigma-σ−ideal. This definition will help us view many notions of “smallness” like being nowhere dense, being meager (see Definition 3.1), being countable, or having measure 0,0,0, as related.

Definition 2.9 (Ideal and σ−\sigma-σ−ideal): An ideal on a set XXX is a collection of subsets of XXX containing ∅\varnothing∅ and closed under arbitrary subsets and finite unions. If the collection is also closed under countable unions it is called a σ−\sigma-σ−ideal.
Proposition 2.10 (Nowhere dense sets form an ideal): The collection of nowhere dense sets in a topological space XXX is an ideal on X.X.X.
The fact that a subset of a nowhere dense set in XXX is also nowhere dense in XXX is obvious. To prove that a finite union of nowhere dense sets in XXX is also nowhere dense in XXX we need only show that for two nowhere dense sets S1S_1S1​ and S2S_2S2​ in X.X.X. Using the characterization in Proposition 2.7 (c), for each nonempty open subset UUU of XXX we can find non-empty open subsets U1U_1U1​ and U2U_2U2​ of XXX such that U1⊆U∖S1U_1 \subseteq U \setminus S_1U1​⊆U∖S1​ and U2⊆U1∖S2.U_2 \subseteq U_1 \setminus S_2.U2​⊆U1​∖S2​. Hence U2⊆U∖(S1∪S2),U_2 \subseteq U \setminus (S_1 \cup S_2),U2​⊆U∖(S1​∪S2​), and therefore again by Proposition 2.7 (c), S1∪S2S_1 \cup S_2S1​∪S2​ is nowhere dense in X.X.X.

The union of countably many nowhere dense sets may not be nowhere dense as the example of Q\mathbb QQ in R\mathbb RR shows.

The next proposition will be useful since we will often have open or dense subsets.

Proposition 2.11 (Nowhere density for subspaces): Let YYY be a subspace of a topological space X,X,X, and let SSS be a subset of Y.Y.Y. If SSS is nowhere dense in Y,Y,Y, then SSS is nowhere dense in X.X.X. Conversely, if YYY is open or dense in XXX and SSS is nowhere dense in X,X,X, then SSS is nowhere dense in Y.Y.Y.

Suppose first that SSS is nowhere dense in Y.Y.Y. Let UUU be a nonempty open subset of XXX that intersects Y.Y.Y. Then U∩YU \cap YU∩Y is open in YYY by the definition of subspace topology. By Proposition 2.7 there exists a nonempty open subset VVV of YYY which is contained in U∩YU \cap YU∩Y and is disjoint from S.S.S. By the definition of subspace topology on Y,Y,Y, there exists a nonempty open subset WWW of XXX such that V=W∩Y.V = W \cap Y.V=W∩Y. This set is such that W∩S=∅W \cap S = \varnothingW∩S=∅ and can taken to be such that W⊆UW \subseteq UW⊆U by taking its intersection with UUU if necessary. By using Proposition 2.7 again we see that SSS is nowhere dense in X.X.X.

Now suppose that YYY is open in XXX and that SSS is nowhere dense in X.X.X. Let UUU be any open subset of Y,Y,Y, which, because YYY is open in X,X,X, is then also open in X.X.X. Therefore, by Proposition 2.7 there exists a nonempty open subset VVV of XXX which is contained in UUU and is disjoint from S.S.S. This set VVV is open in YYY also because V=V∩Y.V = V \cap Y.V=V∩Y. Therefore, by Proposition 2.7 again, SSS is nowhere dense in Y.Y.Y.

Finally suppose that YYY is dense in XXX and that SSS is nowhere dense in X.X.X. Let UUU be any open subset of Y.Y.Y. Then there exists an open subset WWW of XXX such that U=W∩Y.U = W \cap Y.U=W∩Y. By Proposition 2.7 there exists a nonempty open subset VVV of XXX which is contained in WWW and is disjoint from S.S.S. We see that the set V∩YV \cap YV∩Y is nonempty by noting that YYY is dense in XXX and then using Proposition 2.5. It is also open in Y,Y,Y, is contained in U,U,U, and is disjoint from S.S.S. By Proposition 2.7 then, SSS is nowhere dense in Y.Y.Y.

How does nowhere density behave with respect to taking products? As the next theorem shows, the behaviour is simple under finite products. For infinite products an extra (intuitive) condition can cause the product to be nowhere dense. As an example of this condition, let Xn=[0,1]X_n = [0,1]Xn​=[0,1] and Sn=[0,1/2]S_n = [0,1/2]Sn​=[0,1/2] for each n∈N.{n \in \mathbb N}.n∈N. Then for no n∈N,{n \in \mathbb N},n∈N, is SnS_nSn​ is nowhere dense in Xn,X_n,Xn​, but ∏n∈NSn\prod_{n \in \mathbb N} S_n∏n∈N​Sn​ is nowhere dense in ∏n∈NXn.\prod_{n \in \mathbb N} X_n.∏n∈N​Xn​.

Proposition 2.12 (Products of nowhere dense sets): Let AAA be an index set. For all α∈A,\alpha \in A,α∈A, let XαX_\alphaXα​ be a topological space and let Sα⊆Xα.S_\alpha \subseteq X_\alpha.Sα​⊆Xα​.

If AAA is finite, then ∏α∈ASα\prod_{\alpha \in A} S_\alpha∏α∈A​Sα​ is nowhere dense in ∏α∈AXα\prod_{\alpha \in A} X_\alpha∏α∈A​Xα​ if and only if there exists a β∈A\beta \in Aβ∈A such that SβS_\betaSβ​ is nowhere dense in Xβ.X_\beta.Xβ​.

If AAA is infinite, then ∏α∈ASα\prod_{\alpha \in A} S_\alpha∏α∈A​Sα​ is nowhere dense in ∏α∈AXα\prod_{\alpha \in A} X_\alpha∏α∈A​Xα​ if and only if there exists a β∈A\beta \in Aβ∈A such that SβS_\betaSβ​ is nowhere dense in XβX_\betaXβ​ or there exists infinitely many β∈A\beta \in Aβ∈A such that for each such β,\beta,β, SβS_\betaSβ​ is not dense in Xβ.X_\beta.Xβ​.

First note that although the theorem is stated separately for AAA finite and AAA infinite, having only the second statement without the “If AAA is infinite” is sufficient because the “or” part is redundant if AAA is finite. For notational simplicity, let X=∏α∈AXαX = \prod_{\alpha \in A} X_\alphaX=∏α∈A​Xα​ and S=∏α∈ASα.S = \prod_{\alpha \in A} S_\alpha.S=∏α∈A​Sα​.

We start with proving the contrapositive of the if side. Suppose that for each α∈A,\alpha \in A,α∈A, intXα(clXα(Sα))≠∅\mathrm{int}_{X_\alpha}(\mathrm{cl}_{X_\alpha}(S_\alpha)) \neq \varnothingintXα​​(clXα​​(Sα​))=∅ and that clXα(Sα)=Xα\mathrm{cl}_{X_\alpha}(S_\alpha) = X_\alphaclXα​​(Sα​)=Xα​ for all but finitely many α∈A.\alpha \in A.α∈A. Then, using the definition of product topology, it is easily seen that

intX(clX(S))=∏α∈AintXα(clXα(Sα))≠∅, \mathrm{int}_{X}(\mathrm{cl}_{X}(S)) = \prod_{\alpha \in A} \mathrm{int}_{X_\alpha}(\mathrm{cl}_{X_\alpha}(S_\alpha)) \neq \varnothing, intX​(clX​(S))=α∈A∏​intXα​​(clXα​​(Sα​))=∅,

thereby showing that ∏α∈ASα\prod_{\alpha \in A} S_\alpha∏α∈A​Sα​ is not nowhere dense in ∏α∈AXα.\prod_{\alpha \in A} X_\alpha.∏α∈A​Xα​.

For the other side, we split the analysis into two parts depending on which condition is true. If for some β∈A,\beta \in A,β∈A, SβS_\betaSβ​ is nowhere dense in XβX_\betaXβ​, i.e., intXβ(clXβ(Sβ))=∅,\mathrm{int}_{X_\beta}(\mathrm{cl}_{X_\beta}(S_\beta)) = \varnothing,intXβ​​(clXβ​​(Sβ​))=∅, then ∏α∈ASα\prod_{\alpha \in A} S_\alpha∏α∈A​Sα​ is nowhere dense in ∏α∈AXα\prod_{\alpha \in A} X_\alpha∏α∈A​Xα​ since

intX(clX(S))=∏α∈AintXα(clXα(Sα))=∅. \mathrm{int}_X(\mathrm{cl}_X(S)) = \prod_{\alpha \in A} \mathrm{int}_{X_\alpha}(\mathrm{cl}_{X_\alpha}(S_\alpha)) = \varnothing. intX​(clX​(S))=α∈A∏​intXα​​(clXα​​(Sα​))=∅.

On the other hand, if clXβ(Sβ)≠Xβ\mathrm{cl}_{X_\beta}(S_\beta) \neq X_\betaclXβ​​(Sβ​)=Xβ​ for infinitely many β∈A,\beta \in A,β∈A, and UUU is any element from the canonical basis of the product topology on X,X,X, then there exists a γ∈A\gamma \in Aγ∈A such that

πγ(U)=Xγ and clXγ(Sγ)≠Xγ, \pi_\gamma(U) = X_\gamma \text{ and } \mathrm{cl}_{X_\gamma}(S_\gamma) \neq X_\gamma, πγ​(U)=Xγ​ and clXγ​​(Sγ​)=Xγ​,

where πγ ⁣:X→Xγ\pi_\gamma \colon X \to X_\gammaπγ​:X→Xγ​ denotes the canonical projection. Define the nonempty open subset V⊆UV \subseteq UV⊆U by

πγ(V)=Xγ∖clXγ(Sγ) and πα(V)=πα(U). \pi_\gamma(V) = X_\gamma \setminus \mathrm{cl}_{X_\gamma}(S_\gamma) \text{ and } \pi_\alpha(V) = \pi_\alpha(U). πγ​(V)=Xγ​∖clXγ​​(Sγ​) and πα​(V)=πα​(U).

Then V∩S=∅,V \cap S = \varnothing,V∩S=∅, showing that SSS is nowhere dense in X.X.X.

MEAGER SETS

Definition 3.1 (Meager and nonmeager sets): A subset SSS of a topological space XXX is called meager or of first category in XXX if it can be written as a countable union of nowhere dense sets in X.X.X. Otherwise, SSS is called nonmeager or of second category in X.X.X.

We will eschew the usage of the terminology “first category” or “second category” because aside from being non-descriptive, the word “category” in mathematics has “been conscripted for higher service” as S. Berberain remarked (Berberian, 1974).

Remark 3.2: By Proposition 2.11, if YYY is an open or a dense subspace of XXX and S⊆Y,S \subseteq Y,S⊆Y, then SSS is meager (resp. nonmeager) relative to YYY if and only if SSS is meager (resp. nonmeager) relative to X.X.X.

Example 3.3: The notion of meager sets plays a critical role ahead, and therefore some examples are in order.

  1. Rationals Q\mathbb QQ and integers Z\ZZ are meager in R\mathbb RR since they can written as a countable union of singletons which are nowhere dense sets in R.\mathbb R.R.

  2. Every countable set is meager under the setting of Example 2.8.5.

  3. The Cantor set is nowhere dense, and hence also meager. In fact, every nowhere dense in meager.

  4. Any topological space which contains an isolated point ttt is nonmeager, as no set to which ttt belongs can be nowhere dense.

  5. We will show in Section 7.3 that the set of functions that have a derivative at some point is a meagre set in the space of real-valued continuous functions on [0,1][0,1][0,1] endowed with the uniform topology.

Properties Of Meager Sets

Proposition 3.4 (Meager sets form a σ−\sigma-σ−ideal): The collection of meager sets in a topological space XXX form a σ−\sigma-σ−ideal.
A subset of a meager set in XXX is again meager in XXX because a subset of a nowhere dense set in XXX is also nowhere dense in X.X.X. A countable union of meager sets in XXX is again meager in XXX follows from the fact that the Cartesian product of two countable sets is also countable.

It is easily seen that the class of μ−\mu-μ−null sets in a complete measure space (X,X,μ)(X, \mathcal{X}, \mu)(X,X,μ) forms a σ−\sigma-σ−ideal, and so does the class of countable subsets of any set X.X.X. Therefore, being a σ−\sigma-σ−ideal is a characteristic property of many notions of “smallness” of sets. With that said, these notions of “smallness” may of very different nature as the following theorem shows.

Theorem 3.5 (Oxtoby, 1971): Endow the real line R\mathbb RR with the Lebesgue measure λ.\lambda.λ. Then R\mathbb RR can be written as R=A∪B,\mathbb R = A \cup B,R=A∪B, where A∩B=∅,A \cap B = \varnothing,A∩B=∅, AAA is meager in R,\mathbb R,R, and λ(B)=0.\lambda(B) = 0.λ(B)=0.

Suppose {rn}n∈N\{r_n\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{rn​}n∈N​ in an enumeration of the rationals. Consider the family {In,m}n,m∈N\left\{I_{n,m}\right\}_{n,m \in \mathbb N}{In,m​}n,m∈N​ of open intervals defined by

In,m:=(rn−12n+m+1,rn+12n+m+1), I_{n,m} := \left(r_n - \frac{1}{2^{n+m+1}}, r_n + \frac{1}{2^{n+m+1}}\right), In,m​:=(rn​−2n+m+11​,rn​+2n+m+11​),
i.e., In,mI_{n,m}In,m​ is an open interval centered at rnr_nrn​ and has Lebesgue measure 1/2n+m.1/2^{n+m}.1/2n+m. Also define Gm:=⋃n∈NIn,mG_m := \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} I_{n,m}Gm​:=⋃n∈N​In,m​ and B:=⋂m∈NGm.B := \bigcap_{m \in \mathbb N} G_m.B:=⋂m∈N​Gm​.

We claim that λ(B)=0.\lambda(B) = 0.λ(B)=0. To this end, let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0 be arbitrary. Let M∈NM \in \mathbb NM∈N be large enough so that 1/2M<ε.1/2^M < \varepsilon.1/2M<ε. Then since B⊆GMB \subseteq G_MB⊆GM​ and since

λ(GM)≤∑n∈Nλ(In,M)=∑n∈N12n+M=12M<ε, \lambda(G_M) \le \sum_{n \in \mathbb N} \lambda(I_{n,M}) = \sum_{n \in \mathbb N} \frac{1}{2^{n+M}} = \frac{1}{2^M} < \varepsilon, λ(GM​)≤n∈N∑​λ(In,M​)=n∈N∑​2n+M1​=2M1​<ε,
we have λ(B)<ε.\lambda(B) < \varepsilon.λ(B)<ε.

Next, we need to show that

A:=R∖B =⋃m∈N(X∖Gm) A := \mathbb R \setminus B  = \bigcup_{m \in \mathbb N} (X \setminus G_m) A:=R∖B =m∈N⋃​(X∖Gm​)
is meager in R,\mathbb R,R, which we can do by showing that X∖GmX \setminus G_mX∖Gm​ is nowhere dense in R\mathbb RR for each m∈N.m \in \mathbb N.m∈N. But this is obvious from the definition of GmG_mGm​ and from the fact that rationals are dense in R.\mathbb R.R.

It follows from this theorem that every subset of R\mathbb RR can be partitioned into a meager set and a set of Lebesgue measure 0.0.0.

We next prove the Banach category theorem which says that any topological space is “almost” a Baire space (see the next section for the definition of a Baire space). More specifically, given this theorem, we can write any topological space XXX as a union of a Baire space (union of all nonmeager open sets) and a meager set (union of all meager open sets) since in a Baire space every nonempty open set is nonmeager.

Theorem 3.6 (Banach Category Theorem): In a topological space X,X,X, the union of any family of meager open sets is also meager.

Let U\mathcal{U}U be a family of nonempty meager open subsets of X,X,X, and denote by O=⋃U∈UUO = \bigcup_{U \in \mathcal{U}} UO=⋃U∈U​U its union. We want to show that OOO is meager in X.X.X.

Let U\mathscr{U}U denote the set of all collections of pairwise disjoint nonempty open sets in XXX with the property that each member of each collection is a subset of some member of U.\mathcal{U}.U. We will use Zorn's lemma to find a maximal element of U.\mathscr{U}.U. U\mathscr{U}U is partially ordered by set inclusion. Let C\mathscr{C}C be a chain in U.\mathscr{U}.U. To apply Zorn's lemma, we will show that B=⋃R∈CR\mathcal{B} = \bigcup_{\mathcal{R} \in \mathscr{C}} \mathcal{R}B=⋃R∈C​R is an upper bound of C\mathscr{C}C in U\mathscr{U}U, i.e., we need to show B∈U\mathcal{B} \in \mathscr{U}B∈U and R⊆B\mathcal{R} \subseteq \mathcal{B}R⊆B for every R∈C.\mathcal{R} \in \mathscr{C}.R∈C. But both these claims are immediate from our construction. Therefore, by Zorn's lemma, U\mathscr{U}U has a maximal element, say V={Vα : α∈A}\mathcal{V} = \{V_\alpha \,:\, \alpha \in A\}V={Vα​:α∈A} for some index set A.A.A. Denote by V=⋃α∈AVαV = \bigcup_{\alpha \in A} V_\alphaV=⋃α∈A​Vα​ its union.

We next claim that clX(O)∖V\mathrm{cl}_X(O) \setminus VclX​(O)∖V is nowhere dense in X.X.X. Suppose to the contrary that this is not the case, and therefore by Proposition 2.7 (c) there exists a nonempty open subset WWW of X,X,X, such that every nonempty open subset of WWW intersects clX(O)∖V.\mathrm{cl}_X(O) \setminus V.clX​(O)∖V. In particular, WWW intersects clX(O)∖V,\mathrm{cl}_X(O) \setminus V,clX​(O)∖V, which implies W∩O≠∅.W \cap O \neq \varnothing.W∩O=∅. But then W∩U,W \cap U,W∩U, for some U∈U,U \in \mathcal{U},U∈U, is a nonempty open set disjoint from all sets in V,\mathcal{V},V, contradicting the fact that V\mathcal{V}V is maximal.

This fact and the fact that U\mathcal{U}U is a family of meager sets, means that VαV_\alphaVα​ is meager for each α∈A.\alpha \in A.α∈A. Write Vα=⋃n∈NSα,nV_\alpha = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} S_{\alpha, n}Vα​=⋃n∈N​Sα,n​ for some nowhere dense sets Sn,α.S_{n, \alpha}.Sn,α​. Define Sn=⋃α∈ASα,n.S_n = \bigcup_{\alpha \in A} S_{\alpha, n}.Sn​=⋃α∈A​Sα,n​. We now claim that SnS_nSn​ is nowhere dense for each n∈N.{n \in \mathbb N}.n∈N. To see this suppose WWW is a nonempty open set in XXX which intersects Sn.S_n.Sn​. Then WWW intersects Sα,nS_{\alpha, n}Sα,n​ for some α∈A,\alpha \in A,α∈A, and since Sα,nS_{\alpha,n}Sα,n​ is nowhere dense, there exists a nonempty open set W′⊆(W∩Vα)∖Sα,n.W' \subseteq (W \cap V_\alpha) \setminus S_{\alpha, n}.W′⊆(W∩Vα​)∖Sα,n​. This gives W′⊆W∖Sn,W' \subseteq W \setminus S_n,W′⊆W∖Sn​, and thus SnS_nSn​ is nowhere dense.

Finally, note that

O⊆(clX(O)∖V)∪V=(clX(O)∖V)∪⋃n∈NSn, O \subseteq \left( \mathrm{cl}_X(O) \setminus V \right) \cup V = \left( \mathrm{cl}_X(O) \setminus V \right) \cup \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} S_n, O⊆(clX​(O)∖V)∪V=(clX​(O)∖V)∪n∈N⋃​Sn​,

or in other words, OOO is a subset of a countable union of nowhere dense sets, which is to say OOO is meager.

BAIRE SPACES

Definition 4.1 (Baire space): A topological space XXX is said to be a Baire space if every countable union of closed nowhere dense sets in XXX has empty interior in X.X.X.

There are many equivalent formulations for characterizing Baire spaces. Each formulation listed in the next Proposition is more convenient than the other formulations in some proofs, and therefore we will freely use any of them as the definition of a Baire space.

Proposition 4.2 (Equivalent characterizations of Baire space): The following conditions on a topological space XXX are equivalent:

  1. XXX is a Baire space.

  2. The intersection of countably many dense open sets in XXX is dense in X.X.X.

  3. Each nonempty open subset of XXX is nonmeager in X.X.X.

  4. Every meager set in XXX has empty interior in X.X.X.

  5. Complements of meager sets in XXX are dense in X.X.X.

(a)  ⟺  (b)(a) \iff (b)(a)⟺(b): If CCC is a closed nowhere dense subset of X,X,X, then by Proposition 2.3 X∖CX \setminus CX∖C is dense in X.X.X. Therefore, taking complement and using Proposition 2.3 we see that countable union of closed nowhere dense sets in XXX has empty interior if and only if the intersection of countably many dense open sets is dense.

(c)  ⟹  (a)(c) \implies (a)(c)⟹(a): We will prove the contrapositive, i.e., if there exists a nonempty open subset of XXX which is meager in X,X,X, then there exists a countable collection of closed nowhere dense sets in XXX such that the interior of their union is nonempty. To that end, let O=⋃n∈NSnO = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} S_nO=⋃n∈N​Sn​ be a nonempty open subset of XXX which is meager in X,X,X, written as a countable union of nowhere dense sets {Sn}n∈N.\{S_n\}_{n \in \mathbb N}.{Sn​}n∈N​. Since closure of closure of a set in simply the closure, the collection {clX(Sn)}n∈N\left\{\mathrm{cl}_X(S_n)\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{clX​(Sn​)}n∈N​ is a countable collection of closed nowhere dense sets in X.X.X. Therefore, the fact that OOO is nonempty and the following observation finishes the proof:

O=intX(O)=intX(⋃n∈NSn)⊆intX(⋃n∈NclX(Sn)). O = \mathrm{int}_X(O) = \mathrm{int}_X\left(\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} S_n\right) \subseteq \mathrm{int}_X\left(\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{cl}_X(S_n)\right). O=intX​(O)=intX​(n∈N⋃​Sn​)⊆intX​(n∈N⋃​clX​(Sn​)).

(a)  ⟹  (c)(a) \implies (c)(a)⟹(c): We will again prove the contrapositive, i.e., if there exists a countable collection {Fn}n∈N\{F_n\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Fn​}n∈N​ of closed nowhere dense sets in XXX such that the interior of their union is nonempty, then there exists a nonempty open subset of XXX which is meager in X.X.X. Denote the nonempty interior intX(⋃nFn)\mathrm{int}_X\left(\bigcup_n F_n\right)intX​(⋃n​Fn​) by O.O.O. Consider the countable collection {Fn∩O}n∈N\{F_n \cap O\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Fn​∩O}n∈N​ and note that since a subset of a nowhere dense set is also nowhere dense, the collection consists of nowhere dense sets in X.X.X. The set OOO is a subset of ⋃nFn\bigcup_n F_n⋃n​Fn​ and therefore

O=O∩⋃n∈NFn=⋃n∈N(Fn∩O), O = O \cap \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} F_n = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} (F_n \cap O), O=O∩n∈N⋃​Fn​=n∈N⋃​(Fn​∩O),
showing that OOO is meager in X.X.X.

(c)  ⟺  (d)(c) \iff (d)(c)⟺(d): Follows immediately from the observation that a subset of a meager set in XXX is also meager in X.X.X.

Example 4.3:

  1. Trivially, singleton sets are always Baire spaces.

  2. Baire category theorems, proved in Section 5 provide the most common examples of Baire spaces, namely, locally compact Hausdorff spaces and complete pseudo-metric spaces. In particular, the Euclidean spaces Rn\mathbb R^nRn for all n∈Nn \in \mathbb Nn∈N are Baire spaces.

  3. The space Q\mathbb QQ of rationals (with the subspace topology as a subspace of R\mathbb RR) is not a Baire space. Indeed, singletons in Q\mathbb QQ are closed and have empty interior, and therefore Q,\mathbb Q,Q, which can be written as a countable union of all its singletons, cannot be Baire.

  4. The space R∖Q\mathbb R \setminus \mathbb QR∖Q of irrationals (with the subspace topology as a subspace of R\mathbb RR) is a Baire space.

  5. The space N\mathbb NN of natural numbers (with the subspace topology as a subspace of R\mathbb RR) is a Baire space.

Properties Of Baire Spaces

Consider the Baire space R2∖((R∖Q)×{0}).\mathbb R^2 \setminus \left(\left(\mathbb R \setminus \mathbb{Q}\right) \times \{0\}\right).R2∖((R∖Q)×{0}). Its closed subset Q×{0}\mathbb{Q} \times \{0\}Q×{0} is clearly meager. Therefore, a subspace of a Baire space may not be Baire. But if the subspace is open then it is Baire.

Proposition 4.4 (Open Subspaces of Baire are Baire): If XXX is a Baire space and Y⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X is open, then YYY is also a Baire space.

Let {Sn}n∈N\{S_n\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Sn​}n∈N​ be a countable collection of closed nowhere dense sets in Y.Y.Y. We need to show that ⋃n∈NSn\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} S_n⋃n∈N​Sn​ has empty interior in Y.Y.Y. Since SnS_nSn​ is closed in Y,Y,Y, we have clX(Sn)∩Y=Sn\mathrm{cl}_X(S_n) \cap Y = S_nclX​(Sn​)∩Y=Sn​ for each n∈N.n \in \mathbb N.n∈N. We claim that clX(Sn)\mathrm{cl}_X(S_n)clX​(Sn​) is nowhere dense in XXX for each n∈N.n \in \mathbb N.n∈N.

To see this, suppose to the contrary that there exists a nonempty open subset UUU of XXX such that U⊆clX(Sn).U \subseteq \mathrm{cl}_X(S_n).U⊆clX​(Sn​). Then UUU must intersect Sn.S_n.Sn​. Therefore, U∩YU \cap YU∩Y is a nonempty open subset of YYY contained in Sn.S_n.Sn​. This contradicts the fact that SnS_nSn​ is nowhere dense in Y.Y.Y.

We can now use the fact that XXX is a Baire space and get that ⋃n∈NclX(Sn)\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{cl}_X(S_n)⋃n∈N​clX​(Sn​) has empty interior. Now note that if ⋃n∈NSn\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} S_n⋃n∈N​Sn​ didn't have empty interior in Y,Y,Y, then there would exist a nonempty open subset VVV of YYY such that V⊆⋃n∈NSn.V \subseteq \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} S_n.V⊆⋃n∈N​Sn​. This set VVV is also open in XXX because YYY is an open subset of X,X,X, and then V⊆⋃n∈NclX(Sn)V \subseteq \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{cl}_X(S_n)V⊆⋃n∈N​clX​(Sn​) would give a contradiction.

For another proof recall Remark 3.2 and the characterization from Proposition 4.2 (c) of Baire spaces, and then use the fact that an open subset of YYY is also an open subset of X.X.X.

Even a dense subspace of a Baire space may not be Baire as is verified by the fact that Q\mathbb{Q}Q is not a Baire space but is a dense subspace of the Baire space R.\mathbb R.R. However, a dense Gδ−G_\delta-Gδ​−subspace of a Baire space is a Baire space. See Proposition 1.23 in (Haworth and McCoy, 1977) for a proof.

The next proposition will useful is showing that Q\mathbb{Q}Q is not homeomorphic to any complete metric space in Section 7.1.

Proposition 4.5 (Preservation under homeomorphism): If two topological spaces XXX and YYY are homeomorphic, and XXX is a Baire space, then so is Y.Y.Y.
The proof is trivial since being an open subset and being a dense subset are both invariant under homeomorphisms, and since homeomorphisms are bijections, the image of the intersection is the intersection of the images.
Proposition 4.6 (Closure Of Baire Subspace is Baire): Let YYY be a dense subset of a topological space XXX such that it is Baire. Then XXX is also a Baire space.
Suppose to the contrary XXX is not a Baire space. Then by Proposition 4.2 (c) there exists a nonempty open meager subset UUU of X.X.X. But then Y∩UY \cap UY∩U is a nonempty open meager subset of YYY by Proposition 3.4, which contradicts the fact that YYY is a Baire space.

For a topological space X,X,X, an arbitrary union of Baire subspaces of XXX need not be Baire since a singleton set is a Baire space. But we have the following two results if the Baire subspaces are open or if the union is of a finite family.

Proposition 4.7 (Arbitrary Union of Open Baire Spaces): In a topological space X,X,X, the union of any family of open Baire subspaces is a Baire space.
Let U\mathcal{U}U be a family of open Baire subspaces of X.X.X. Suppose VVV is an open meager subset of ⋃U∈UU.\bigcup_{U \in \mathcal{U}} U.⋃U∈U​U. Let U∈UU \in \mathcal{U}U∈U be such that it intersects V.V.V. Then U∩VU \cap VU∩V is open and meager in U.U.U. Therefore, by Proposition 4.2 (e), ⋃U∈UU\bigcup_{U \in \mathcal{U}} U⋃U∈U​U is Baire since UUU is Baire.
Proposition 4.8 (Finite Union of Baire Spaces): In a topological space X,X,X, the union of a finite family of Baire subspaces is a Baire space.

It is sufficient to show the proposition for two Baire subspaces. Without loss of generality, we can let X=Y∪Z,X = Y \cup Z,X=Y∪Z, where YYY and ZZZ are Baire spaces, and we want to show that XXX is a Baire space.

X∖clX(Y)X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(Y)X∖clX​(Y) and X∖clX(Z)X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(Z)X∖clX​(Z) are open in ZZZ and Y,Y,Y, respectively, and hence by Proposition 4.4, they both Baire spaces. By Proposition 4.7 then

B=(X∖clX(Y))∪(X∖clX(Z))=X∖(clX(Y)∩clX(Z)) B = \left(X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(Y)\right) \cup \left(X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(Z)\right) = X \setminus \left(\mathrm{cl}_X(Y) \cap \mathrm{cl}_X(Z)\right) B=(X∖clX​(Y))∪(X∖clX​(Z))=X∖(clX​(Y)∩clX​(Z))
is an open Baire subspace of X.X.X. By Proposition 4.6, clX(Y)\mathrm{cl}_X(Y)clX​(Y) is a Baire space, and since X∖clX(B)X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(B)X∖clX​(B) is its open subset, by Proposition 4.4, X∖clX(B)X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(B)X∖clX​(B) is a Baire space. But B∪(X∖clX(B))B \cup \left(X \setminus \mathrm{cl}_X(B)\right)B∪(X∖clX​(B)) is a Baire subspace by Proposition 4.7 and is dense in X,X,X, and therefore by Proposition 4.6, XXX is Baire.

Products of Baire spaces may not be Baire space. The analysis is involved. See (Cohen, 1976) for details.

As is intuitively expected, a disjoint sum of Baire spaces is Baire.

Proposition 4.9 (Disjoint sums): Every disjoint topological sum of Baire spaces is a Baire space.
For Baire spaces {Xα}α∈A,\{X_\alpha\}_{\alpha \in A},{Xα​}α∈A​, let X=⨆α∈AXαX = \bigsqcup_{\alpha \in A} X_\alphaX=⨆α∈A​Xα​ be their disjoint sum and let UUU be an open subset of X.X.X. By Proposition 4.4, U∩XαU \cap X_\alphaU∩Xα​ is a Baire space if the intersection is nonempty. Since U=⋃α(U∩Xα),U = \bigcup_{\alpha} (U \cap X_\alpha),U=⋃α​(U∩Xα​), where the union is over all such α,\alpha,α, by Proposition 4.7, UUU is a Baire space. XXX can now be written as a union of open Baire spaces and hence is Baire.

The last property we consider is the relation of being Baire with the underlying topology. Suppose (X,T)(X, \mathcal T)(X,T) is a topological space. Then (X,2X)(X, 2^X)(X,2X) is always a Baire space since it can be completely metrized using the discrete metric

d(x,y)={1if x≠y0if x=y,x,y∈X.\begin{aligned} d(x,y) =\begin{cases}1 &\text{if } x \neq y \\0 &\text{if } x = y\end{cases}, \quad x,y \in X.\end{aligned}d(x,y)={10​if x=yif x=y​,x,y∈X.​
Therefore, even if (X,T)(X, \mathcal{T})(X,T) is a Baire space, (X,S)(X, \mathcal{S})(X,S) may not be a Baire space if S\mathcal{S}S is strictly coarser than T.\mathcal{T}.T.

BAIRE CATEGORY THEOREMS

In this section we prove the main results of this blog post, the Baire category theorems. They state that if XXX is a locally compact Hausdorff space or a complete pseudometric space, then XXX is a Baire space. These theorems will have many applications as we will see in Section 7. Proving both these results involves constructing a nested sequence of open sets and then showing that the intersection of their closures is nonempty. We start with proving the Baire category theorem for locally compact Hausdorff spaces, for which we will need a few results which we prove next.

Since locally compact spaces have different meanings in literature, let us define it for our use case.

Definition 5.1 (Locally compact): A topological space XXX is said to be locally compact at x∈Xx \in Xx∈X if there is some compact subspace C⊆XC \subseteq XC⊆X that contains a neighborhood of x.x.x. If XXX is locally compact at each of its points, XXX is said to be locally compact.

The first result we need is an equivalent characterization of locally compact Hausdorff spaces. This characterization will allow us to construct our nested sequence of open sets. But even before that we need a simple lemma.

Lemma 5.2 (A point outside a compact subspace in a Hausdorff space can be separated): If YYY is a compact subspace of a Hausdorff space XXX and x∈X∖Y,x \in X \setminus Y,x∈X∖Y, then there exist disjoint open subsets UUU and VVV of XXX such that x∈Ux \in Ux∈U and Y⊆V.Y \subseteq V.Y⊆V.
For each y∈Y,y \in Y,y∈Y, there exists a pair of disjoint open sets (Uy,Vy)(U_y, V_y)(Uy​,Vy​) such that x∈Uyx \in U_yx∈Uy​ and y∈Vy,y \in V_y,y∈Vy​, because XXX is Hausdorff. By our construction, the collection {Vy}y∈Y\{V_y\}_{y \in Y}{Vy​}y∈Y​ is an open cover for the compact set Y,Y,Y, and therefore, there exists a finite subcover, say {Vi}i=1n.\{V_i\}_{i=1}^n.{Vi​}i=1n​. Define V=⋃i=1nViV = \bigcup_{i=1}^n V_iV=⋃i=1n​Vi​ and define U=⋂i=1nUi,U = \bigcap_{i=1}^n U_i,U=⋂i=1n​Ui​, giving us the desired disjoint open sets.
Proposition 5.3 (Equivalent characterization of local compactness in Hausdorff spaces): Let XXX be a Hausdorff space. Then XXX is locally compact if and only if given an open subset U⊆XU \subseteq XU⊆X and a point x∈U,x \in U,x∈U, there is an open subset V⊆XV \subseteq XV⊆X containing xxx such that clX(V)\mathrm{cl}_X(V)clX​(V) is compact and clX(V)⊆U.\mathrm{cl}_X(V) \subseteq U.clX​(V)⊆U.

The if side is easy: Given a point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and letting U=XU=XU=X in the hypothesis, there is an open subset V⊆XV \subseteq XV⊆X containing xxx such that clX(V)\mathrm{cl}_X(V)clX​(V) is compact, and therefore clX(V)\mathrm{cl}_X(V)clX​(V) serves as the compact set containing the neighborhood VVV of x.x.x.

For the other side, suppose XXX is a locally compact Hausdorff space, and let UUU be an open set in XXX with x∈U.x \in U.x∈U. Let X∗X^*X∗ be the Alexandroff one-point compactification of X.X.X. Then since UUU is open in X,X,X, it is also open in X∗,X^*,X∗, and thus X∗∖UX^* \setminus UX∗∖U is closed in X∗.X^*.X∗. Since X∗X^*X∗ is compact, X∗∖UX^* \setminus UX∗∖U is a compact subspace of X∗.X^*.X∗. Since X∗X^*X∗ is Hausdorff, we can use Lemma 5.2 to find disjoint open subsets VVV and WWW of X∗X^*X∗ such that x∈Vx \in Vx∈V and X∗∖U⊆W.X^* \setminus U \subseteq W.X∗∖U⊆W. The closure clX∗(V)\mathrm{cl}_{X^*}(V)clX∗​(V) is compact and satisfies clX∗(V)∩(X∗∖U)=∅.\mathrm{cl}_{X^*}(V) \cap (X^* \setminus U) = \varnothing.clX∗​(V)∩(X∗∖U)=∅. Therefore, clX∗(V)=clX(V)\mathrm{cl}_{X^*}(V) = \mathrm{cl}_X(V)clX∗​(V)=clX​(V) is compact and satisfies clX(V)⊆U,\mathrm{cl}_X(V) \subseteq U,clX​(V)⊆U, as desired.

We next prove a proposition that allows us to make claims about the non-emptiness of intersection of a family of closed sets satisfying the finite intersection property. Recall that a collection C\mathcal{C}C of subsets of XXX is said to have the finite intersection property if every finite subcollection of C\mathcal{C}C has nonempty intersection.

Proposition 5.4 (Equivalent characterization of compactness): A topological space XXX is compact if and only if for every collection C\mathcal{C}C of closed sets in XXX having the finite intersection property, the intersection ⋂C∈CC\bigcap_{C \in \mathcal{C}} C⋂C∈C​C is nonempty.

XXX is compact means that given any collection U\mathcal{U}U of open sets, if no finite subcollection covers X,X,X, then U\mathcal{U}U cannot cover X.X.X. Define the collection C={X∖U : U∈U}\mathcal{C} = \{X \setminus U \,:\, U \in \mathcal{U}\}C={X∖U:U∈U} of closed sets in X,X,X, and note that we could have constructed U\mathcal{U}U given C\mathcal{C}C similarly. It is easy to see that the collection U\mathcal{U}U does not cover XXX if and only if ⋂C∈CC\bigcap_{C \in \mathcal{C}} C⋂C∈C​C is nonempty, and similarly a finite subcollection {U1,…,Un}\{U_1, \ldots, U_n\}{U1​,…,Un​} of U\mathcal{U}U does not cover XXX if and only if the intersection ⋂i=1nCi\bigcap_{i=1}^n C_i⋂i=1n​Ci​ of the corresponding closed sets from C\mathcal{C}C is nonempty.

Therefore, the statement “given any collection U\mathcal{U}U of open sets, if no finite subcollection covers X,X,X, then U\mathcal{U}U cannot cover XXX”, is equivalent to the statement “given any collection C\mathcal{C}C of closed sets, if every finite intersection of elements of C\mathcal{C}C is nonempty, then the intersection ⋂C∈CC\bigcap_{C \in \mathcal{C}} C⋂C∈C​C is nonempty”.

We have now done most of the legwork to establish the Baire category theorem for locally compact Hausdorff spaces.

Theorem 5.5 (Baire category theorem for locally compact Hausdorff space): Every locally compact Hausdorff space XXX is a Baire space.

Let {Un}n∈N\{U_n\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Un​}n∈N​ be a collection of dense open sets in X.X.X. We want to show that their intersection is also dense in X,X,X, i.e., we want to show that for any nonempty open subset V⊆X,V \subseteq X,V⊆X, the intersection

V∩(⋂n∈NUn)\begin{aligned} V \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_n \right)\end{aligned}V∩(n∈N⋂​Un​)​
is nonempty. To that end, fix an arbitrary nonempty open subset V⊆X.V \subseteq X.V⊆X. Since U1U_1U1​ is dense in X,X,X, there exists a point x1∈V∩U1.x_1 \in V \cap U_1.x1​∈V∩U1​. Proposition 5.3 implies that there exists an open subset V1⊆XV_1 \subseteq XV1​⊆X containing x1x_1x1​ such that clX(V1)\mathrm{cl}_X(V_1)clX​(V1​) is compact and clX(V1)⊆V∩U1.\mathrm{cl}_X(V_1) \subseteq V \cap U_1.clX​(V1​)⊆V∩U1​. Similarly, for n>1,n > 1,n>1, we use Proposition 5.3 to get a nonempty open subset Vn⊆XV_n \subseteq XVn​⊆X such that clX(Vn)\mathrm{cl}_X(V_n)clX​(Vn​) is compact and clX(Vn)⊆Vn−1∩Un.\mathrm{cl}_X(V_n) \subseteq V_{n-1} \cap U_n.clX​(Vn​)⊆Vn−1​∩Un​.

The sequence clX(V1)⊇clX(V2)⊇⋯\mathrm{cl}_X(V_1) \supseteq \mathrm{cl}_X(V_2) \supseteq \cdotsclX​(V1​)⊇clX​(V2​)⊇⋯ is a collection of closed sets in the compact space clX(V1)\mathrm{cl}_X(V_1)clX​(V1​) satisfying the finite intersection property, and therefore by Proposition 5.4, the intersection ⋂n∈NclX(Vn)\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{cl}_X(V_n)⋂n∈N​clX​(Vn​) is nonempty. But note that by our construction

⋂n∈NclX(Vn)⊆V∩(⋂n∈NUn),\begin{aligned} \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{cl}_X(V_n) \subseteq V \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_n \right),\end{aligned}n∈N⋂​clX​(Vn​)⊆V∩(n∈N⋂​Un​),​
showing that V∩(⋂n∈NUn)V \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_n \right)V∩(⋂n∈N​Un​) is nonempty.

The proof of Baire category theorem for complete pseudometric space proceeds in a very similar fashion, except here we use completeness instead of compactness to show that the intersection of the closures of the sequence of open sets constructed is nonempty. Recall that, unlike metric spaces, in a pseudometric space it is possible for the distance between two distinct points to be 0.0.0.

Theorem 5.6 (Baire category theorem for complete pseudometric space): Every complete metric space (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) is a Baire space.

(X,d)(X, d)(X,d) is equipped with the pseudometric topology generated by the open balls

Br(p)={x∈X : d(x,p)<r},p∈X, r>0,\begin{aligned} B_r(p) = \{x \in X \,:\, d(x,p) < r\}, \quad p \in X,\, r > 0,\end{aligned}Br​(p)={x∈X:d(x,p)<r},p∈X,r>0,​
which form a basis for the topology. For any subset AAA of X,X,X, denote by
d(A)=sup⁡{d(s,t) : s,t∈A}\begin{aligned} d(A) = \sup \{d(s,t) \,:\, s,t \in A\}\end{aligned}d(A)=sup{d(s,t):s,t∈A}​
the diameter of A,A,A, and define d∗(A):=min⁡{1,d(A)}.d^*(A) := \min \{1, d(A)\}.d∗(A):=min{1,d(A)}. Observe that if A⊆B⊆XA \subseteq B \subseteq XA⊆B⊆X then d∗(A)≤d∗(B).d^*(A) \le d^*(B).d∗(A)≤d∗(B).

Let {Un}n∈N\{U_n\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Un​}n∈N​ be a collection of dense open sets in X.X.X. We want to show that their intersection is also dense in X,X,X, i.e., we want to show that for any nonempty open subset V⊆X,V \subseteq X,V⊆X, the intersection

V∩(⋂n∈NUn)\begin{aligned} V \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_n \right)\end{aligned}V∩(n∈N⋂​Un​)​
is nonempty. To that end, fix an arbitrary nonempty open subset V⊆X.V \subseteq X.V⊆X. Since U1U_1U1​ is dense in X,X,X, there exists a point x1∈V∩U1.x_1 \in V \cap U_1.x1​∈V∩U1​. By the definition of a basis, we can choose r∈(0,1)r \in (0,1)r∈(0,1) such that Br(x1)⊆V∩U1.B_r(x_1) \subseteq V \cap U_1.Br​(x1​)⊆V∩U1​. If we define r′:=d(Br(x1)),r' := d(B_r(x_1)),r′:=d(Br​(x1​)), then by triangle inequality r′/2≤r<1.r'/2 \le r < 1.r′/2≤r<1. Thus if we define V1=Br′/4(x1)V_1 = B_{r'/4}(x_1)V1​=Br′/4​(x1​) we have
clX(V1)⊆{x∈X : d(x,x1)≤r′4}⊆Br(x1)⊆V∩U1,\begin{aligned} \mathrm{cl}_X(V_1) \subseteq \left\{x \in X \,:\, d(x,x_1) \le \frac{r'}{4}\right\} \subseteq B_r(x_1) \subseteq V \cap U_1,\end{aligned}clX​(V1​)⊆{x∈X:d(x,x1​)≤4r′​}⊆Br​(x1​)⊆V∩U1​,​
and by triangle inequality
d(V1)≤r′2=d∗(Br(p))2≤d∗(V∩U1)2≤d(V∩U1)2.\begin{aligned} d(V_1) \le \frac{r'}{2} = \frac{d^*(B_r(p))}{2} \le \frac{d^*(V \cap U_1)}{2} \le \frac{d(V \cap U_1)}{ 2}.\end{aligned}d(V1​)≤2r′​=2d∗(Br​(p))​≤2d∗(V∩U1​)​≤2d(V∩U1​)​.​
Similarly, for n>1,n > 1,n>1, we construct a nonempty open subset Vn⊆XV_n \subseteq XVn​⊆X such that
clX(Vn)⊆Vn−1∩Un\begin{aligned} \mathrm{cl}_X(V_n) \subseteq V_{n-1} \cap U_n\end{aligned}clX​(Vn​)⊆Vn−1​∩Un​​
and
d(Vn)≤d∗(Vn−1)2≤d(Vn−1)2.\begin{aligned} d(V_n) \le \frac{d^*(V_{n-1}) }{ 2} \le \frac{d(V_{n-1}) }{ 2}.\end{aligned}d(Vn​)≤2d∗(Vn−1​)​≤2d(Vn−1​)​.​

We claim that ⋂n∈NclX(Vn)\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{cl}_X(V_n)⋂n∈N​clX​(Vn​) is nonempty. Since d∗(V1)≤1d^*(V_1) \le 1d∗(V1​)≤1 and d(Vn+1)≤d∗(Vn)/2,d(V_{n+1}) \le d^*(V_n) / 2,d(Vn+1​)≤d∗(Vn​)/2, we have d(Vn)≤2−n+1d(V_{n}) \le 2^{-n+1}d(Vn​)≤2−n+1 for each n∈N.n \in \mathbb N.n∈N. Each of these sets is nonempty and therefore we can choose xn∈Vnx_n \in V_nxn​∈Vn​ for each n∈N.{n \in \mathbb N}.n∈N. The sequence {xn}n∈N\{x_n\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{xn​}n∈N​ becomes a Cauchy sequence and therefore since XXX is complete there exists x∈Xx \in Xx∈X such that it is the limit of this sequence. By our construction, if m≤n,m \le n,m≤n, then xn∈Vm⊆clX(Vm).x_n \in V_m \subseteq \mathrm{cl}_X(V_m).xn​∈Vm​⊆clX​(Vm​). Thus, x∈clX(Vn)x \in \mathrm{cl}_X(V_n)x∈clX​(Vn​) for each n∈N.{n \in \mathbb N}.n∈N. This shows that x∈⋂nclX(Vn).x \in \bigcap_n \mathrm{cl}_X(V_n).x∈⋂n​clX​(Vn​).

But note that by our construction

⋂n∈NclX(Vn)⊆V∩(⋂n∈NUn),\begin{aligned} \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{cl}_X(V_n) \subseteq V \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_n \right),\end{aligned}n∈N⋂​clX​(Vn​)⊆V∩(n∈N⋂​Un​),​
showing that V∩(⋂n∈NUn)V \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_n \right)V∩(⋂n∈N​Un​) is nonempty.

As a trivial (but useful!) corollary a complete metric space is a Baire space.

Locally compact Hausdorff spaces and completely metrizable spaces are of very different nature, and therefore it is surprising that they both are Baire spaces and in this sense have many common properties. As an example of a locally compact Hausdorff that isn't a complete metric space, consider [0,1]J[0,1]^J[0,1]J for uncountable set JJJ or (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) with the subspace topology with respect to R.\mathbb R.R. In fact, [0,1]J[0,1]^J[0,1]J is a compact Hausdorff space that isn't even metrizable. On the other hand, NN\mathbb N^\mathbb NNN (which is homeomorphic to the space of irrationals) and infinite-dimensional Hilbert spaces are examples of complete metric spaces that aren't locally compact Hausdorff. Finally, the Sorgenfrey plane and the Niemytzki/Moore plane are Baire spaces which are neither complete pseudometric spaces nor a locally compact Hausdorff spaces.

TOPOLOGICAL GAMES

A topological game is typically a 2-player game where the two players choose some objects related to the topological structure of a space, such as points, closed subsets, open covers, etc., in each round of the game with a goal in mind. The conditions on a play to be winning for a player also involves topological notions such as closure, a convergence, etc. Remarkably, it turns out that topological games can be used to define notions such as Baire property, Baire spaces, completeness properties, convergence properties, separation properties, continuous images, Suslin sets, etc. Viewing these topological notions through the lens of topological games often provides more insight and is even sometimes a more natural perspective.

In this section we will discuss two 2-player games, Banach-Mazur game and Choquet game. These games are closely tied to meager sets and Baire spaces.

In the period 1930s and 1940s mathematicians from the Lwów school in Poland, which included Banach, Ulam, Kuratowski, Steinhaus, Mazur, Kac, Alexandroff, von Neumann, Orlicz, Sobolev, Borsuk, Zygmund, Schauder, Eilenberg among others, collaboratively discussed problems, mainly in topology and functional analysis. In 1935, Banach started a famous notebook, called the Scottish Book, where these mathematicians proposed mathematical conjectures. In the same year Mazur proposed a topological game related to the Baire category theorem. A solution was proposed by Banach and therefore the game is now known as Banach-Mazur game (Telegarsky, 1987). It was the first infinite positional game of perfect information to be studied.

Banach-Mazur Game

Let us state and prove the Banach-Mazur game as it proposed originally by Mazur. Instead of general topological spaces XXX we will be limiting ourselves to sets on the real line equipped with the usual Euclidean topology. We use the phrase closed interval to refer to intervals of the form [a,b][a,b][a,b] for a<ba < ba<b.

Definition 6.1 (Banach-Mazur Game): Player PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ is dealt an arbitrary subset AAA of a closed interval I0I_0I0​. The complement B=I0∖AB = I_0 \setminus AB=I0​∖A is dealt to the player PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​. The game, denoted by BM ⁣(A,B)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( A, B\right)BM(A,B), is played as follows: PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ chooses any closed sub-interval I1⊆I0I_1 \subseteq I_0I1​⊆I0​; then PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ chooses any closed sub-interval I2⊆I1I_2 \subseteq I_1I2​⊆I1​; and so on, alternatively. Together the players determine a nested sequence I0⊆I1⊆I2⊆⋯I_0 \subseteq I_1 \subseteq I_2 \subseteq \cdotsI0​⊆I1​⊆I2​⊆⋯ of closed intervals, PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ choosing those with odd index and PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ choosing those with even index. PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ wins if and only if A∩(⋂n∈NIn)≠∅A \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} I_n \right) \neq \varnothingA∩(⋂n∈N​In​)=∅; otherwise, PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ wins.

The following theorem due to Mazur states that if AAA is meager then there exists a strategy which PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ can use to win the game no matter what PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ plays.

Theorem 6.2: If I0I_0I0​ is any closed interval and A∪BA \cup BA∪B a partition of I0I_0I0​, then there exists a winning strategy for PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ for the game BM ⁣(A,B)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( A, B\right)BM(A,B) if AAA is meager in I0I_0I0​.
Write A=⋃n∈NAnA = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} A_nA=⋃n∈N​An​ as a countable union of nowhere dense sets in I0I_0I0​. Then at each step n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N, PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ can choose a closed interval I2nI_{2n}I2n​ such that I2n⊆I2n−1∖AnI_{2n} \subseteq I_{2n-1} \setminus A_nI2n​⊆I2n−1​∖An​. Then A∩(⋂n∈NI2n)=∅A \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} I_{2n} \right) = \varnothingA∩(⋂n∈N​I2n​)=∅, and therefore no matter how PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ plays, PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ will win.

Mazur conjectured that only when AAA is meager in I0I_0I0​ does there exist a strategy which PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ can use to win. Banach proved this result. Before we give the proof, let us formalize what we mean by a "strategy".

Definition 6.3 (Strategy): A strategy for either player is a sequence of closed-interval-valued functions each of which specify the choice of the set by the player in the corresponding move while satisfying the rules of the game. More specifically, for PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ denote the strategy by the sequence {fn}n∈N\left\{ f_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{fn​}n∈N​ such that for each n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N, I2n=fn(I0,I1,…,I2n−1)⊆I2n−1.\begin{aligned} I_{2n} = f_n(I_0, I_1, \ldots, I_{2n-1}) \subseteq I_{2n-1}.\end{aligned}I2n​=fn​(I0​,I1​,…,I2n−1​)⊆I2n−1​.​ Then this is a winning strategy for PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ if and only if ⋂n∈NIn⊆B\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} I_n \subseteq B⋂n∈N​In​⊆B for any valid choice of {I2n−1}n∈N\left\{ I_{2n-1}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{I2n−1​}n∈N​ by PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​.
Theorem 6.4: If I0I_0I0​ is any closed interval and A∪BA \cup BA∪B a partition of I0I_0I0​, then there exists a winning strategy for PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ for the game BM ⁣(A,B)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( A, B\right)BM(A,B) if and only if AAA is meager in I0I_0I0​.

We have already proved the if part in Theorem 6.2. So assume that {fn}n∈N\left\{ f_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{fn​}n∈N​ is a winning strategy for PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​. We want to show that AAA is meager, which we do by showing that AAA is a subset of a countable union ⋃n∈N(I0∖Gn)\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} (I_0 \setminus G_n)⋃n∈N​(I0​∖Gn​) of nowhere dense sets. This we will do by constructing open sets {Gn}n∈N\left\{ G_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Gn​}n∈N​ such that each GnG_nGn​ is dense in I0I_0I0​. The construction proceeds by induction to first construct clever families of sets {Ji1,…,in : n,i1,…,in∈N}\left\{ J_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \,:\, n, i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N\right\}{Ji1​,…,in​​:n,i1​,…,in​∈N} and {Ki1,…,in : n,i1,…,in∈N}\left\{ K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \,:\, n, i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N\right\}{Ki1​,…,in​​:n,i1​,…,in​∈N} which are used to define {Gn}n∈N\left\{ G_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Gn​}n∈N​ and also a particular sequence {In}n∈N\left\{ I_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{In​}n∈N​ for which, since {fn}n∈N\left\{ f_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{fn​}n∈N​ is a winning strategy, we will use the fact that ⋂n∈NIn⊆B\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} I_n \subseteq B⋂n∈N​In​⊆B. To that end let us start by constructing the families {Ji1,…,in : n,i1,…,in∈N}\left\{ J_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \,:\, n, i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N\right\}{Ji1​,…,in​​:n,i1​,…,in​∈N} and {Ki1,…,in : n,i1,…,in∈N}\left\{ K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \,:\, n, i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N\right\}{Ki1​,…,in​​:n,i1​,…,in​∈N}.

The collection S\mathcal SS of all closed intervals that have rational endpoints and are contained in intR ⁣(I0)\mathrm{int}_{ \mathbb R}\!\left( I_0\right)intR​(I0​) is countable and therefore S\mathcal SS can be thought of as a sequence. We define two sequences {Jn}n∈N\left\{ J_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Jn​}n∈N​ and {Kn=f1(I0,Jn)}n∈N\left\{ K_n = f_1(I_0, J_n)\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Kn​=f1​(I0​,Jn​)}n∈N​ of closed intervals as follows: J1J_1J1​ is the first element of S\mathcal SS; for n>1n > 1n>1, define JnJ_nJn​ to be the first term of S\mathcal SS contained in I0∖(⋃i=1n−1Ki)I_0 \setminus \left( \bigcup_{i=1}^{n-1}K_i \right)I0​∖(⋃i=1n−1​Ki​). We then have

(ii) the sets {Kn}n∈N\left\{ K_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Kn​}n∈N​ are pairwise disjoint, and
