The first and the second property are obvious from the construction and the fact that Kn⊆f1(I0,Jn)K_n \subseteq f_1(I_0, J_n)Kn​⊆f1​(I0​,Jn​). The third property follows from the fact that rationals are dense in R\mathbb RR, and therefore for every open subset of I0I_0I0​ we can find a closed interval with rational endpoints lying inside this open set. Note that the elements of the sequence {Jn}n∈N\left\{ J_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Jn​}n∈N​ are contained in intR ⁣(I0)\mathrm{int}_{ \mathbb R}\!\left( I_0\right)intR​(I0​).

Similarly, for each m∈Nm \in \mathbb Nm∈N, let {Jm,n}n∈N\left\{ J_{m,n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Jm,n​}n∈N​ be a sequence of closed intervals contained in intR ⁣(Km)\mathrm{int}_{ \mathbb R}\!\left( K_m\right)intR​(Km​) such that the sets {Km,n=f2(I0,Jm,Km,Jm,n)}n∈N\left\{ K_{m,n} = f_2(I_0, J_m, K_m, J_{m,n})\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Km,n​=f2​(I0​,Jm​,Km​,Jm,n​)}n∈N​ are pairwise disjoint, and ⋃n∈NintR ⁣(Km,n)\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{int}_{ \mathbb R}\!\left( K_{m,n}\right)⋃n∈N​intR​(Km,n​) is dense in KmK_mKm​. Now recall Proposition 2.6, which implies that ⋃m,n∈NintR ⁣(Km,n)\bigcup_{m,n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{int}_{ \mathbb R}\!\left( K_{m,n}\right)⋃m,n∈N​intR​(Km,n​) is dense in I0I_0I0​.

Proceeding inductively, we define two families of closed intervals

{Ji1,…,in : n,i1,…,in∈N}, and{Ki1,…,in=fn(I0,Ji1,Ki1,Ji1,i2,Ki1,i2,…,Ji1,…,in) : n,i1,…,in∈N} \left\{ J_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \,:\, n, i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N\right\} \text{, and} \\ \left\{ K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} = f_n(I_0, J_{i_1}, K_{i_1}, J_{i_1, i_2}, K_{i_1, i_2}, \ldots, J_{i_1, \ldots, i_n}) \,:\, n, i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N\right\} {Ji1​,…,in​​:n,i1​,…,in​∈N}, and{Ki1​,…,in​​=fn​(I0​,Ji1​​,Ki1​​,Ji1​,i2​​,Ki1​,i2​​,…,Ji1​,…,in​​):n,i1​,…,in​∈N}
satisfying the following properties

(i) Ji1,…,in⊆intR ⁣(Ki1,…,in)J_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \subseteq \mathrm{int}_{ \mathbb R}\!\left( K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n}\right)Ji1​,…,in​​⊆intR​(Ki1​,…,in​​),

(ii) for each n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N, the sets {Ki1,…,in : i1,…,in∈N}\left\{ K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \,:\, i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N\right\}{Ki1​,…,in​​:i1​,…,in​∈N} are pairwise disjoint, and

(iii) for each n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N, ⋃i1,…,in∈NintR ⁣(Ki1,…,in)\bigcup_{i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{int}_{ \mathbb R}\!\left( K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n}\right)⋃i1​,…,in​∈N​intR​(Ki1​,…,in​​) is dense in I0I_0I0​.

Having defined these families, note that if {in}n∈N\left\{ i_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{in​}n∈N​ is any arbitrary sequence of positive integers, then the sequence {In}n∈N\left\{ I_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{In​}n∈N​ such that I2n−1=Ji1,…,in and I2n=Ki1,…,in,n∈N\begin{aligned} I_{2n-1} = J_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \text{ and } I_{2n} = K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n}, \quad {n \in \mathbb N}\end{aligned}I2n−1​=Ji1​,…,in​​ and I2n​=Ki1​,…,in​​,n∈N​ is a valid play of the game consistent with the strategy {fn}n∈N\left\{ f_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{fn​}n∈N​ of PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​. By hypothesis, {fn}n∈N\left\{ f_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{fn​}n∈N​ is a winning strategy, and therefore ⋂n∈NIn⊆B\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} I_n \subseteq B⋂n∈N​In​⊆B.

Define the sequence {Gn}n∈N\left\{ G_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Gn​}n∈N​ of open sets by

Gn=⋃i1,…,in∈NintR ⁣(Ki1,…,in),\begin{aligned} G_n = \bigcup_{i_1, \ldots, i_n \in \mathbb N} \mathrm{int}_{ \mathbb R}\!\left( K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n}\right),\end{aligned}Gn​=i1​,…,in​∈N⋃​intR​(Ki1​,…,in​​),​
and let E=⋂n∈NGnE = \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} G_nE=⋂n∈N​Gn​ be their intersection. Then E⊆BE \subseteq BE⊆B because if x∈Ex \in Ex∈E, then xxx is in every GnG_nGn​, which with property (ii) gives a unique sequence {in}n∈N\left\{ i_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{in​}n∈N​ such that x∈Ki1,…,inx \in K_{i_1, \ldots, i_n}x∈Ki1​,…,in​​ for every n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N, which if used to define {In}n∈N\left\{ I_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{In​}n∈N​ like in (2) and noting Ki1,…,in⊆Ji1,…,inK_{i_1, \ldots, i_n} \subseteq J_{i_1, \ldots, i_n}Ki1​,…,in​​⊆Ji1​,…,in​​ gives x∈⋂n∈NIn⊆Bx \in \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} I_n \subseteq Bx∈⋂n∈N​In​⊆B. But now note that
A=I0∖B⊆I0∖E=⋃n∈N(I0∖Gn).\begin{aligned} A = I_0 \setminus B \subseteq I_0 \setminus E = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} (I_0 \setminus G_n).\end{aligned}A=I0​∖B⊆I0​∖E=n∈N⋃​(I0​∖Gn​).​
By the definition of GnG_nGn​ and property (iii), I0∖GnI_0 \setminus G_nI0​∖Gn​ is nowhere dense in I0I_0I0​ for each n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N. This finishes the proof.

This theorem gives new insight into the sense in which a meager set is "small" - even the advantage of being the first player is not enough. When can the player PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ be sure to win? This is answered by the next theorem, and is a simple consequence of our previous theorem.

Theorem 6.5: If I0I_0I0​ is any closed interval and A∪BA \cup BA∪B a partition of I0I_0I0​, then there exists a winning strategy for PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ for the game BM ⁣(A,B)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( A, B\right)BM(A,B) if and only if BBB is meager in some closed interval I1⊆I0I_1 \subseteq I_0I1​⊆I0​.

If such a closed interval I1I_1I1​ exists, then PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ can start by choosing I1I_1I1​ and then by following the strategy of PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ in Theorem 6.2, PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ can ensure than B∩(⋂n∈NIn)=∅B \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} I_n \right) = \varnothingB∩(⋂n∈N​In​)=∅. The intersection ⋂n∈NIn\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} I_n⋂n∈N​In​ is nonempty (see the proof of Theorem 5.6 where a generalization of this well-known fact was proved), and therefore this is a winning strategy for PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​.

On the other hand, if PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ has a winning strategy, then suppose he chooses I1I_1I1​ as his first move. After this move, the game BM ⁣(A,B)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( A, B\right)BM(A,B) becomes the game BM ⁣(I1∩B,I1∩A)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( I_1 \cap B, I_1 \cap A\right)BM(I1​∩B,I1​∩A) and player PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ becomes player PI1∩A\mathcal P_{I_1 \cap A}PI1​∩A​. Then using Theorem 6.4 PI1∩A\mathcal P_{I_1 \cap A}PI1​∩A​ has a winning strategy only if I1∩BI_1 \cap BI1​∩B is meager in I1I_1I1​.

Is it possible that neither player has a winning strategy? Yes, for example, if A=I0∩BA = I_0 \cap BA=I0​∩B, where BBB is the Bernstein set, which is defined to be a subset of R\mathbb RR such that both BBB and R∖B\mathbb R \setminus BR∖B intersect every uncountable closed set. For a proof of this result, see Chapter-6 in (Oxtoby, 1971).

Generalization

In (Oxtoby, 1957), Oxtoby proved a generalization of the above game. The game is still called the Banach-Mazur game. We will not be proving this result, but will state it for completeness.

Definition 6.6 (Banach-Mazur Game): Let XXX be any topological space, and let G\mathcal GG be a specified class of subsets of XXX such that

(i) each element of G\mathcal GG has a nonempty interior in XXX, and

(ii) every nonempty open subset of XXX contains an element of G\mathcal GG.

Let X=A∪BX = A \cup BX=A∪B be an arbitrary partition of XXX. The game BM ⁣(A,B)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( A, B\right)BM(A,B) is played by two players PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ and PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ as follows: PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ chooses any G1∈GG_1 \in \mathcal GG1​∈G; then PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ chooses any G2∈GG_2 \in \mathcal GG2​∈G such that G2⊆G1G_2 \subseteq G_1G2​⊆G1​; and so on alternatively. Together the players determine a nested sequence G1⊆G2⊆⋯G_1 \subseteq G_2 \subseteq \cdotsG1​⊆G2​⊆⋯ of elements from G\mathcal GG, with PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ choosing those with odd index and PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ choosing those with even index.

PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ wins if and only if A∩(⋂n∈NGn)≠∅A \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} G_n \right) \neq \varnothingA∩(⋂n∈N​Gn​)=∅; otherwise PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ wins.

Theorem 6.7 ((Oxtoby, 1957)): (i) Using the notion above, there exists a winning strategy for PB\mathcal P_{B}PB​ for the game BM ⁣(A,B)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( A, B\right)BM(A,B) if and only if AAA is meager in XXX.

(ii) If we assume that XXX is a complete metric space, there exists a winning strategy for PA\mathcal P_{A}PA​ for the game BM ⁣(A,B)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( A, B\right)BM(A,B) if and only if BBB is meager in some nonempty open subset of XXX.

The proof is very similar to the proof of the Theorems 6.4 and 6.5. For details see (Oxtoby, 1957).

Choquet Game

Choquet game proposed by Choquet in his book (Choquet, 1969) is closely related to the Banach-Mazur game.

Definition 6.8 (Choquet Game): Let XXX be a nonempty topological space. The _Choquet game} CXC_XCX​ of XXX is a game with two players PX\mathcal P_XPX​ and P∅\mathcal P_\varnothingP∅​ taking turns in choosing nonempty open subsets of XXX as follows: Player PX\mathcal P_XPX​ chooses G1G_1G1​, then player P∅\mathcal P_\varnothingP∅​ chooses G2⊆G1G_2 \subseteq G_1G2​⊆G1​; and so on alternatively. Together the players determine a nested sequence G1⊆G2⊆⋯G_1 \subseteq G_2 \subseteq \cdotsG1​⊆G2​⊆⋯ of nonempty open subsets of XXX, with PX\mathcal P_XPX​ choosing those with odd index and P∅\mathcal P_\varnothingP∅​ choosing those with even index.

P∅\mathcal P_\varnothingP∅​ wins this game if and only if ⋂n∈NGn≠∅\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} G_n \neq \varnothing⋂n∈N​Gn​=∅; otherwise PX\mathcal P_XPX​ wins.

Note the similarity between this game and the Banach-Mazur game specified by taking A=XA = XA=X and G\mathcal GG to be the collection of all nonempty open subsets of XXX in Definition 6.6. In the Banach-Mazur game we say PX\mathcal P_XPX​ wins BM ⁣(X,∅)\mathrm{BM}\!\left( X, \varnothing\right)BM(X,∅) if and only if ⋂n∈NGn≠∅\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} G_n \neq \varnothing⋂n∈N​Gn​=∅, while in the Choquet game we say P∅\mathcal P_\varnothingP∅​ wins CXC_XCX​ if and only if ⋂n∈NGn≠∅\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} G_n \neq \varnothing⋂n∈N​Gn​=∅. This swap changes a lot though as the following theorem demonstrates.

Theorem 6.9: A nonempty topological space XXX is a Baire space if and only if player PX\mathcal P_XPX​ has no winning strategy in the Choquet game CXC_XCX​.

Having shown the relation between the Choquet and Banach-Mazur games, let us change the notation a little for convenience. Let us denote the players PX\mathcal P_XPX​ and P∅\mathcal P_\varnothingP∅​ by P1\mathcal P_1P1​ and P2\mathcal P_2P2​ respectively for players 111 and 222. The choices of P1\mathcal P_1P1​ which is the collection {G2n−1}n∈N\left\{ G_{2n-1}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{G2n−1​}n∈N​ is denoted by {Un}n∈N\left\{ U_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Un​}n∈N​ and the choices of P2\mathcal P_2P2​ which is the collection {G2n}n∈N\left\{ G_{2n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{G2n​}n∈N​ is denoted by {Vn}n∈N\left\{ V_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Vn​}n∈N​. The strategy for P1\mathcal P_1P1​ is the sequence of nonempty-open-subset-valued functions {fn}n∈N\left\{ f_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{fn​}n∈N​ such that f1f_1f1​ gives the first choice U1U_1U1​ of P1\mathcal P_1P1​ and the remaining functions satisfy

Un=fn(U1,V1,…,Vn−1)⊆Vn−1.\begin{aligned} U_n = f_n(U_1, V_1, \ldots, V_{n-1}) \subseteq V_{n-1}.\end{aligned}Un​=fn​(U1​,V1​,…,Vn−1​)⊆Vn−1​.​
Then {fn}n∈N\left\{ f_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{fn​}n∈N​ is a winning strategy for P1\mathcal P_1P1​ if and only if ⋂n∈NUn=∅\bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_n = \varnothing⋂n∈N​Un​=∅.

We will prove the contrapositives in each direction. For the if side, assume that XXX is not a Baire space. We will show that P1\mathcal P_1P1​ has a winning strategy by constructing a sequence of nonempty open sets {Un}n∈N\left\{ U_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Un​}n∈N​ such that their intersection is empty.

Since XXX isn't a Baire space, Proposition 4.2 (b)(b)(b) implies that there exists nonempty open set U1U_1U1​ in XXX and a sequence {On}n∈N\left\{ O_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{On​}n∈N​ of dense open sets in XXX such that U1∩(⋂n∈NOn)=∅.U_1 \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} O_n \right) = \varnothing.U1​∩(⋂n∈N​On​)=∅. This nonempty open set U1U_1U1​ becomes the first move for P1.\mathcal P_1.P1​. Suppose P2\mathcal P_2P2​ now plays V1⊆U1V_1 \subseteq U_1V1​⊆U1​ for any nonempty open set V1V_1V1​. Note that V1∩O1≠∅V_1 \cap O_1 \neq \varnothingV1​∩O1​=∅ since O1O_1O1​ is dense in X.X.X. Let P1\mathcal P_1P1​ play U2=V1∩O1⊆V1.U_2 = V_1 \cap O_1 \subseteq V_1.U2​=V1​∩O1​⊆V1​. In the nthn^{\text{th}}nth move, P1\mathcal P_1P1​ plays Un=Vn−1∩On⊆Vn−1,U_n = V_{n-1} \cap O_n \subseteq V_{n-1},Un​=Vn−1​∩On​⊆Vn−1​, which is nonempty because OnO_nOn​ is dense in XXX. But then we have

⋂n∈NUn⊆U1∩(⋂n∈NOn)=∅.\begin{aligned} \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_n \subseteq U_1 \cap \left( \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} O_n \right) = \varnothing.\end{aligned}n∈N⋂​Un​⊆U1​∩(n∈N⋂​On​)=∅.​

For the other side, suppose P1\mathcal P_1P1​ has a winning strategy {fn}n∈N\left\{ f_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{fn​}n∈N​, and U1U_1U1​ is his first move. We will show that U1U_1U1​ is not Baire, which coupled with Proposition 4.4 will show that XXX is not Baire. Then proceeding as we do in proofs of Theorems 6.4 and 6.7 we construct a clever family of open sets through which we construct a sequence of open dense sets {Gn}n∈N\left\{ G_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Gn​}n∈N​ in U1.U_1.U1​. We then show that their intersection is empty, thereby showing that U1U_1U1​ is not Baire.

APPLICATIONS

This section gives a few interesting applications of Baire category theorems. One of the most common applications of Baire category theorems is in proving the three big guns of functional analysis, namely Open Mapping Theorem, Closed Graph Theorem, Uniform Boundedness Principle. But these proofs can can be found very easily in any functional analysis text (see (Megginson, 1998) for example), so we will skip them.

Usually these applications follow a similar recipe: Suppose that SSS is a desired property for the elements of some nonempty complete pseudo-metric space or some locally compact Hausdorff space XXX. One way to show that SSS is nonempty is to show that X∖SX \setminus SX∖S is meager in XXX. This is therefore usually an overkill, and why results like these are often surprising.

Q\mathbb QQ Is Not Homeomorphic To Any Complete Metric Space

It is well-known that Q\mathbb QQ, with the subspace topology with respect to R\mathbb RR with its usual Euclidean topology, is not a complete metric space. But completeness is not a topological property as can be seen with the example of R\mathbb RR and (0,1)(0,1)(0,1), both equipped with the usual topology, being homeomorphic under the homeomorphism

(0,1)∋x↦tan⁡(−π2+πx)∈R,\begin{aligned} (0,1) \ni x \mapsto \tan\left( -\frac{\pi}{2} + \pi x \right) \in \mathbb R,\end{aligned}(0,1)∋x↦tan(−2π​+πx)∈R,​
but R\mathbb RR is complete while (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) is not. It is a simple consequence of Baire category theorem for complete metric spaces that Q\mathbb QQ is not homeomorphic to any complete metric spaces.

Theorem 7.1: Q\mathbb QQ is not homeomorphic to any complete metric spaces.
Let's first show that Q\mathbb QQ is not a Baire space. Indeed, singletons in Q\mathbb QQ are closed and have empty interior, and therefore Q\mathbb QQ, which can be written as a countable union of all its singletons, cannot be Baire. Now by Proposition 4.5 and by Baire category theorem for complete metric spaces, Q\mathbb QQ cannot be homeomorphic to any complete metric spaces.

Infinite-Dimensional Banach Spaces

We start with a very simple application of Baire's category theorem.

Theorem 7.2: If XXX is an infinite dimensional Banach space, then every Hamel basis of XXX is uncountable.

Suppose to the contrary that {vn}n∈N\left\{ v_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{vn​}n∈N​ is a countable Hamel basis for an infinite dimensional Banach space XXX. For each n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N, define Fn=⟨v1,…,vn⟩F_n = \langle v_1, \ldots, v_n \rangleFn​=⟨v1​,…,vn​⟩ to be the span of the first nnn vectors. Then by the definition of a Hamel basis, X=⋃n∈NFnX = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} F_nX=⋃n∈N​Fn​. Recall at this point that XXX is a complete metric space, and therefore a Baire space.

Now note that each FnF_nFn​, being a finite-dimensional normed space, is complete. A complete subspace of a complete metric space is closed, and therefore FnF_nFn​ is closed in XXX.

Next, we prove that each FnF_nFn​ is nowhere dense. Since it is closed, we just need to show that FnF_nFn​ has empty interior in XXX. Suppose to the contrary that is not the case, and there exists an open ball Br(x0)={y∈X : ∥y−x∥<r}B_r(x_0) = \left\{ y \in X \,:\, \left\lVert y-x\right\rVert < r\right\}Br​(x0​)={y∈X:∥y−x∥<r} centered at some point x0∈Xx_0 \in Xx0​∈X for some r>0r > 0r>0 satisfying Br(x0)⊆FnB_r(x_0) \subseteq F_nBr​(x0​)⊆Fn​. We now note that every point in XXX can be rescaled and translated so that the transformation belongs to the ball Br(x0)B_r(x_0)Br​(x0​): if x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, then z=x0+r2∥x∥x∈Br(x0)z = x_0 + \frac{r}{2\left\lVert x\right\rVert}x \in B_r(x_0)z=x0​+2∥x∥r​x∈Br​(x0​). Since FnF_nFn​ is a subspace, this implies that x=2∥x∥r(z−x0)∈Fnx = \frac{2\left\lVert x\right\rVert}{r}(z-x_0) \in F_nx=r2∥x∥​(z−x0​)∈Fn​, implying X⊆FnX \subseteq F_nX⊆Fn​, a contradiction.

These two facts together with the fact that XXX is a Baire space imply that XXX has empty interior, which is absurd.

A similar reasoning can be used to prove that the linear space of all polynomials in one variable PPP is not a Banach space in any norm. This is because PPP can be written as P=⋃n∈NPnP = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} P_nP=⋃n∈N​Pn​, where PnP_nPn​ is the subspace of PPP containing polynomials of degree at most nnn. Each PnP_nPn​ is closed and nowhere dense in PPP, and therefore PPP cannot be a Baire space, which, in particular, means that it cannot be a Banach space.

A Generic Element Of C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] Is Nowhere Differentiable

Let us first make precise the meaning of "generic".

Definition 7.3: Let XXX be a topological space and S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X. If X∖SX \setminus SX∖S is meager, we say that SSSholds generically, or that a generic element of XXX is in SSS. (Sometimes the word typical is used instead of generic.)
Definition 7.4: Let C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] denote the collection of all real-valued continuous functions on [0,1][0,1][0,1]. We endow this collection with the sup norm,
∥f∥∞:=sup⁡x∈[0,1]∣f(x)∣,f∈C[0,1].\begin{aligned} \left\lVert f\right\rVert_\infty := \sup_{x \in [0,1]} \left\lvert f(x) \right\rvert, \quad f \in C[0,1].\end{aligned}∥f∥∞​:=x∈[0,1]sup​∣f(x)∣,f∈C[0,1].​
This makes C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] into a Banach space (see (Megginson, 1998) for a proof).

We now prove that a generic element of C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] is nowhere differentiable. In fact, we will prove something stronger.

Theorem 7.5: Let D+D_+D+​ be the collection of all members fff of C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] for which there is a point xf∈[0,1)x_f \in [0,1)xf​∈[0,1) at which fff has a finite right-hand derivative. Then D+D_+D+​ is meager in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1].

We first note that C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] being a complete metric space is a Baire space by Theorem 5.6, and therefore the intersection of countably many dense open sets {Un}n∈N\left\{ U_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Un​}n∈N​ in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] is dense in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1]. This then implies that C[0,1]∖⋂n∈NUnC[0,1] \setminus \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_nC[0,1]∖⋂n∈N​Un​ is meager in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1]. Our strategy will be to define this sequence {Un}n∈N\left\{ U_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Un​}n∈N​ in such a way that D+⊆C[0,1]∖⋂n∈NUnD_+ \subseteq C[0,1] \setminus \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_nD+​⊆C[0,1]∖⋂n∈N​Un​, thereby showing that D+D_+D+​ is meager in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1].

To this end, let

Un={f∈C[0,1] : sup⁡{∣f(y)−f(x)y−x∣ : y∈(x,x+1n)}>n,  ∀ x∈[0,1−1n]},\begin{aligned} U_n = \left\{ f \in C[0,1] \,:\, \sup \left\{ \left\lvert \frac{f(y) - f(x)}{y-x} \right\rvert \,:\, y \in \left( x, x + \frac{1}{n} \right)\right\} > n, \; \forall \, x \in \left[0, 1 - \frac{1}{n} \right]\right\},\end{aligned}Un​={f∈C[0,1]:sup{∣∣​y−xf(y)−f(x)​∣∣​:y∈(x,x+n1​)}>n,∀x∈[0,1−n1​]},​
and note that a function f∈C[0,1]f \in C[0,1]f∈C[0,1] with a finite right-hand derivative at some point in [0,1)[0,1)[0,1) cannot lie in every UnU_nUn​. Therefore, D+⊆C[0,1]∖⋂n∈NUnD_+ \subseteq C[0,1] \setminus \bigcap_{n \in \mathbb N} U_nD+​⊆C[0,1]∖⋂n∈N​Un​. What remains to show that each UnU_nUn​ is open and dense in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1]. Fix an arbitrary n0∈Nn_0 \in \mathbb Nn0​∈N.

Un0U_{n_0}Un0​​ is open in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1]: We show this by showing that C[0,1]∖Un0C[0,1] \setminus U_{n_0}C[0,1]∖Un0​​ is closed in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1]. Suppose {fm}m∈N\left\{ f_m\right\}_{m \in \mathbb N}{fm​}m∈N​ is a sequence in C[0,1]∖Un0C[0,1] \setminus U_{n_0}C[0,1]∖Un0​​ that converges to f0∈C[0,1]f_0 \in C[0,1]f0​∈C[0,1]. Since C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] is a metric space, to show C[0,1]∖Un0C[0,1] \setminus U_{n_0}C[0,1]∖Un0​​ is closed in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1], it is sufficient to show that f0∈C[0,1]∖Un0f_0 \in C[0,1] \setminus U_{n_0}f0​∈C[0,1]∖Un0​​. By the definition of Un0U_{n_0}Un0​​, for each m∈Nm \in \mathbb Nm∈N, there exists xm∈[0,1−1/n0]x_m \in [0, 1 - 1/n_0]xm​∈[0,1−1/n0​] such that

∣fm(y)−fm(xm)y−xm∣≤n0,∀ y∈(xm,xm+1n0).\begin{aligned} \left\lvert \frac{f_m(y) - f_m(x_m)}{y-x_m} \right\rvert \le n_0, \quad \forall \, y \in \left( x_m, x_m + \frac{1}{n_0} \right).\end{aligned}∣∣​y−xm​fm​(y)−fm​(xm​)​∣∣​≤n0​,∀y∈(xm​,xm​+n0​1​).​
The sequence {xm}m∈N\left\{ x_m\right\}_{m \in \mathbb N}{xm​}m∈N​ lies in the compact set [0,1−1/n0][0, 1-1/n_0][0,1−1/n0​], and therefore there exists a convergent subsequence, say {xmk}k∈N\left\{ x_{m_k}\right\}_{k \in \mathbb N}{xmk​​}k∈N​ converging to x0∈[0,1−1/n0]x_0 \in [0, 1-1/n_0]x0​∈[0,1−1/n0​]. ∣fmk(y)−fmk(xmk)y−xmk∣→k→∞∣f0(y)−f0(x0)y−x0∣.\begin{aligned} \left\lvert \frac{f_{m_k}(y) - f_{m_k}(x_{m_k})}{y-x_{m_k}} \right\rvert \xrightarrow{k \to \infty} \left\lvert \frac{f_0(y) - f_0(x_0)}{y-x_0} \right\rvert.\end{aligned}∣∣​y−xmk​​fmk​​(y)−fmk​​(xmk​​)​∣∣​k→∞​∣∣​y−x0​f0​(y)−f0​(x0​)​∣∣​.​

Un0U_{n_0}Un0​​ is dense in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1]: Recall the Stone-Weierstrass theorem (Folland, 1999) which implies that polynomials on [0,1][0,1][0,1] (with the subspace topology), denoted P[0,1]P[0,1]P[0,1], are dense in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1]. Given ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 and M>0M > 0M>0, the figure above shows how to construct a function in C[0,1]C[0,1]C[0,1] that has norm ϵ\epsilonϵ and absolute value of right-hand derivative greater than MMM at each point of [0,1)[0,1)[0,1).

A Special Infinitely Differentiable Function

We end our applications with a very curious result.

Theorem 7.6: If f ⁣:R→Rf \colon \mathbb R \to \mathbb Rf:R→R is infinitely differentiable, and for every x∈Rx \in \mathbb Rx∈R there is a nonnegative integer nnn such that f(n)(x)=0f^{(n)}(x) = 0f(n)(x)=0, then fff is a polynomial.

We will prove by contradiction. So suppose fff is not a polynomial. Define the set

X={x∈R : for every interval (a,b) containing x, the restriction f↾(a,b) is not a polynomial},\begin{aligned} X = \left\{ x \in \mathbb R \,:\, \text{for every interval } (a,b) \text{ containing } x \text{, the restriction } f \restriction_{(a,b)} \text{ is not a polynomial}\right\},\end{aligned}X={x∈R:for every interval (a,b) containing x, the restriction f↾(a,b)​ is not a polynomial},​
and note that since fff is not a polynomial, XXX is nonempty. It is easy to see that XXX is closed with all of its points being limit points. Define the sequence of sets {Sn}n∈N\left\{ S_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N}{Sn​}n∈N​ by
Sn={x : f(n)(x)=0},\begin{aligned} S_n = \left\{ x \,:\, f^{(n)}(x) = 0\right\},\end{aligned}Sn​={x:f(n)(x)=0},​
and note that for each n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N, by the continuity of f(n)f^{(n)}f(n), SnS_nSn​ is closed. Using the property of fff in the hypothesis, we can write
X=⋃n∈N(X∩Sn).\begin{aligned} X = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb N} \left( X \cap S_n \right).\end{aligned}X=n∈N⋃​(X∩Sn​).​
Now note that XXX being closed is also complete, and therefore by the Baire category theorem is a Baire space. Since each X∩SnX \cap S_nX∩Sn​ is closed in XXX, this implies that there exists N∈NN \in \mathbb NN∈N such that X∩SNX \cap S_NX∩SN​ is not nowhere dense in XXX. Equivalently, this means there exists a nonempty open subset of XXX contained in X∩SNX \cap S_NX∩SN​. So there exists an interval (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) such that

(i) X∩(a,b)X \cap (a,b)X∩(a,b) is nonempty (note that it's open in XXX), and

(ii) X∩(a,b)⊆SNX \cap (a,b) \subseteq S_NX∩(a,b)⊆SN​.

Suppose x∈X∩(a,b)x \in X \cap (a,b)x∈X∩(a,b). Then since xxx is a limit point of X∩(a,b)X \cap (a,b)X∩(a,b), there exists a sequence {xn}n∈N⊆X∩(a,b)\left\{ x_n\right\}_{n \in \mathbb N} \subseteq X \cap (a,b){xn​}n∈N​⊆X∩(a,b) converging to xxx. Property (ii)(ii)(ii) implies that f(N)(xn)=0f^{(N)}(x_n) = 0f(N)(xn​)=0 for all n∈N{n \in \mathbb N}n∈N. Using the definition of derivative, this implies f(N+1)(x)=0f^{(N+1)}(x) = 0f(N+1)(x)=0 showing x∈SN+1x \in S_{N+1}x∈SN+1​. Proceeding similarly we get,

(iii) x∈Smx \in S_mx∈Sm​ for all m≥Nm \ge Nm≥N and every x∈X∩(a,b)x \in X \cap (a,b)x∈X∩(a,b).

Consider any maximal interval (c,d)⊆((a,b)∖X)(c,d) \subseteq \left( (a,b) \setminus X \right)(c,d)⊆((a,b)∖X). Since (c,d)(c,d)(c,d) lies outside XXX, fff is a polynomial on (c,d)(c,d)(c,d), say of degree kkk. This implies that f(k)≠0f^{(k)} \neq 0f(k)=0 on (c,d)(c,d)(c,d). Continuity of f(k)f^{(k)}f(k) implies that in fact f(k)≠0f^{(k)} \neq 0f(k)=0 on [c,d][c,d][c,d]. Since one of ccc or ddd must be in XXX, using property (iii)(iii)(iii) this implies k<Nk < Nk<N.

This along with property (iii)(iii)(iii) shows that f(N)=0f^{(N)} = 0f(N)=0 on the full interval (a,b)(a,b)(a,b). But then this means the restriction f↾(a,b)f \restriction_{(a,b)}f↾(a,b)​ is a polynomial which contradicts property (i)(i)(i).
